Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Each time you take a step, 200 muscles work in unison
to lift your foot, propel it forward, and set it down. It's just one of the many thousands
of tasks performed by the muscular system. This network of over 650 muscles
covers the body and is the reason we can blink, smile, run, jump, and stand upright. It's even responsible for 
the heart's dependable thump. First, what exactly 
is the muscular system? It's made up of three main muscle types: skeletal muscle, which attaches
via tendons to our bones, cardiac muscle, which is only
found in the heart, and smooth muscle, which lines
the blood vessels and certain organs, like the intestine and uterus. All three types are 
made up of muscle cells, also known as fibers,
bundled tightly together. These bundles receive signals from
the nervous system that contract the fibers, which in turn
generates force and motion. This produces almost all
the movements we make. Some of the only parts of the body whose motions aren't governed 
by the muscular system are sperm cells, the hair-like cilia in our airways, and certain white blood cells. Muscle contraction can be split
into three main types. The first two, shortening muscle fibers
and lengthening them, generate opposing forces. So the biceps will shorten
while the triceps will lengthen or relax, pulling up the arm and making it 
bend at the elbow. This allows us to, say, pick up a book, or if the muscle relationship 
is reversed, put it down. This complementary partnership
exists throughout the muscular system. The third type of contraction
creates a stabilizing force. In these cases, the muscle fibers
don't change in length, but instead keep the muscles rigid. This allows us to grip a mug of coffee
or lean against a wall. It also maintains our posture
by holding us upright. Skeletal muscles form the bulk
of the muscular system, make up about 30-40% of the body's weight, and generate most of its motion. Some muscles are familiar to us,
like the pectorals and the biceps. Others may be less so,
like the buccinator, a muscle that attaches your cheek
to your teeth, or the body's tiniest skeletal muscle, a one-millimeter-long tissue fragment
called the stapedius that's nestled deep inside the ear. Wherever they occur, skeletal muscles are
connected to the somatic nervous system, which gives us almost complete control
over their movements. This muscle group also contains
two types of muscle fibers to refine our motions even further,
slow-twitch and fast-twitch. Fast-twitch fibers react instantly
when triggered but quickly use up their energy
and tire out. Slow-twitch fibers, on the other hand,
are endurance cells. They react and use energy slowly
so they can work for longer periods. A sprinter will accumulate more
fast-twitch muscles in her legs through continuous practice, enabling her to quickly, if briefly,
pick up the pace, whereas back muscles contain 
more slow-twitch muscles to maintain your posture all day. Unlike the skeletal muscles, the body's
cardiac and smooth muscles are managed by 
the autonomic nervous system beyond our direct control. That makes your heart thump
roughly 3 billion times over the course of your life, which supplies the body 
with blood and oxygen. Autonomic control also contracts
and relaxes smooth muscle in a rhythmic cycle. That pumps blood through the smooth
internal walls of blood vessels, enables the intestine to constrict and
push food through the digestive system, and allows the uterus to contract
when a person is giving birth. As muscles work, they also use energy
and produce an important byproduct, heat. In fact, muscle provides 
about 85% of your warmth, which the heart and blood vessels
then spread evenly across the body via the blood. Without that, we couldn't maintain
the temperature necessary for our survival. The muscular system 
may be largely invisible to us, but it leaves its mark on almost
everything we do, whether it's the blink of an eye
or a race to the finish line.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What type of muscle makes up the muscular system?
Options: A. Skeletal muscle, B. Cardiac muscle, C. Smooth muscle, D. Skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscle
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the body's weight does skeletal muscle make up? Options: A. 10-20%, B. 20-30%, C. 30-40%, D. 40-50% Correct Option: C
Question 2: Which of the following is an example of a stabilizing force produced by muscle contraction? Options: A. Bending the elbow, B. Gripping a mug of coffee, C. Lifting a heavy object, D. Walking down the street Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the main difference between fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscle fibers? Options: A. Fast-twitch fibers are used for endurance, while slow-twitch fibers are used for quick movements, B. Fast-twitch fibers react slowly, while slow-twitch fibers react quickly, C. Fast-twitch fibers use up energy quickly, while slow-twitch fibers use up energy slowly, D. Fast-twitch fibers are found in the heart, while slow-twitch fibers are found in the muscles Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the role of the autonomic nervous system in controlling the body's cardiac and smooth muscles? Options: A. It gives us almost complete control over their movements, B. It manages their movements beyond our direct control, C. It has no role in controlling their movements, D. It only controls their movements in certain situations Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the main function of the muscular system? Options: A. To provide warmth to the body, B. To generate movement and force, C. To regulate body temperature, D. To digest food Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the name of the smallest skeletal muscle in the human body? Options: A. Stapedius, B. Buccinator, C. Pectorals, D. Biceps Correct Option: A
Question 7: What percentage of the body's movements are governed by the muscular system? Options: A. 50-60%, B. 60-70%, C. 70-80%, D. Almost all Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the role of muscle contraction in generating movement? Options: A. It only generates opposing forces, B. It only generates stabilizing forces, C. It generates opposing and stabilizing forces, D. It has no role in generating movement Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the main difference between the somatic nervous system and the autonomic nervous system? Options: A. The somatic nervous system gives us almost complete control over our movements, while the autonomic nervous system manages our movements beyond our direct control, B. The somatic nervous system manages our movements beyond our direct control, while the autonomic nervous system gives us almost complete control over our movements, C. Both systems give us almost complete control over our movements, D. Both systems manage our movements beyond our direct control Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main byproduct of muscle contraction? Options: A. Heat, B. Movement, C. Force, D. Energy Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 5 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

However, since Question 5 does not explicitly ask about the types of muscles that make up the muscular system, I re-examined the generated MCQs and found that none of them exactly match the ground truth MCQ.

But if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the overall content and intent, I would choose Question 5, as it is related to the muscular system and its functions.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2

and tire out. Slow-twitch fibers, on the other hand,

the temperature necessary for our survival. The muscular system 
may be largely invisible to us, but it leaves its mark on almost
everything we do, whether it's the blink of an eye
or a race to the finish line.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Fast twitch muscle cells:
Options: A. Use energy slowly, B. Would be abundant in the muscles of a sprinter, C. Have lots of nerve cells, D. Help us to stand upright
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3

Each time you take a step, 200 muscles work in unison
to lift your foot, propel it forward, and set it down. It's just one of the many thousands
of tasks performed by the muscular system. This network of over 650 muscles
covers the body and is the reason we can blink, smile, run, jump, and stand upright. It's even responsible for 
the heart's dependable thump. First, what exactly 
is the muscular system? It's made up of three main muscle types: skeletal muscle, which attaches
via tendons to our bones, cardiac muscle, which is only
found in the heart, and smooth muscle, which lines
the blood vessels and certain organs, like the intestine and uterus. All three types are

bundled tightly together. These bundles receive signals from

may be largely invisible to us, but it leaves its mark on almost

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Enables us to stand and sit upright, B. Means it helps us to lift heavy things, C. Makes the muscle very tense
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

the movements we make. Some of the only parts of the body whose motions aren't governed 
by the muscular system are sperm cells, the hair-like cilia in our airways, and certain white blood cells. Muscle contraction can be split
into three main types. The first two, shortening muscle fibers
and lengthening them, generate opposing forces. So the biceps will shorten
while the triceps will lengthen or relax, pulling up the arm and making it 
bend at the elbow. This allows us to, say, pick up a book, or if the muscle relationship 
is reversed, put it down. This complementary partnership
exists throughout the muscular system. The third type of contraction
creates a stabilizing force. In these cases, the muscle fibers
don't change in length, but instead keep the muscles rigid. This allows us to grip a mug of coffee
or lean against a wall. It also maintains our posture
by holding us upright. Skeletal muscles form the bulk
of the muscular system, make up about 30-40% of the body's weight, and generate most of its motion. Some muscles are familiar to us,
like the pectorals and the biceps. Others may be less so,
like the buccinator, a muscle that attaches your cheek
to your teeth, or the body's tiniest skeletal muscle, a one-millimeter-long tissue fragment
called the stapedius that's nestled deep inside the ear. Wherever they occur, skeletal muscles are
connected to the somatic nervous system, which gives us almost complete control
over their movements. This muscle group also contains
two types of muscle fibers to refine our motions even further,
slow-twitch and fast-twitch. Fast-twitch fibers react instantly
when triggered but quickly use up their energy
and tire out. Slow-twitch fibers, on the other hand,
are endurance cells. They react and use energy slowly
so they can work for longer periods. A sprinter will accumulate more
fast-twitch muscles in her legs through continuous practice, enabling her to quickly, if briefly,
pick up the pace, whereas back muscles contain 
more slow-twitch muscles to maintain your posture all day. Unlike the skeletal muscles, the body's
cardiac and smooth muscles are managed by 
the autonomic nervous system beyond our direct control. That makes your heart thump
roughly 3 billion times over the course of your life, which supplies the body 
with blood and oxygen. Autonomic control also contracts
and relaxes smooth muscle in a rhythmic cycle. That pumps blood through the smooth
internal walls of blood vessels, enables the intestine to constrict and
push food through the digestive system, and allows the uterus to contract
when a person is giving birth. As muscles work, they also use energy
and produce an important byproduct, heat. In fact, muscle provides 
about 85% of your warmth, which the heart and blood vessels
then spread evenly across the body via the blood. Without that, we couldn't maintain
the temperature necessary for our survival. The muscular system 
may be largely invisible to us, but it leaves its mark on almost
everything we do, whether it's the blink of an eye
or a race to the finish line.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Without the muscular system, we wouldn’t be able to make most of the body heat that we require.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the body's weight does skeletal muscle make up? Options: A. 10-20%, B. 20-30%, C. 30-40%, D. 40-50% Correct Option: C
Question 2: Which of the following is an example of a stabilizing force produced by muscle contraction? Options: A. Bending the elbow, B. Gripping a mug of coffee, C. Lifting a heavy object, D. Walking down the street Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the main difference between fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscle fibers? Options: A. Fast-twitch fibers are used for endurance, while slow-twitch fibers are used for quick movements, B. Fast-twitch fibers react slowly, while slow-twitch fibers react quickly, C. Fast-twitch fibers use up energy quickly, while slow-twitch fibers use up energy slowly, D. Fast-twitch fibers are found in the heart, while slow-twitch fibers are found in the muscles Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the role of the autonomic nervous system in controlling the body's cardiac and smooth muscles? Options: A. It gives us almost complete control over their movements, B. It manages their movements beyond our direct control, C. It has no role in controlling their movements, D. It only controls their movements in certain situations Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the main function of the muscular system? Options: A. To provide warmth to the body, B. To generate movement and force, C. To regulate body temperature, D. To digest food Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the name of the smallest skeletal muscle in the human body? Options: A. Stapedius, B. Buccinator, C. Pectorals, D. Biceps Correct Option: A
Question 7: What percentage of the body's movements are governed by the muscular system? Options: A. 50-60%, B. 60-70%, C. 70-80%, D. Almost all Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the role of muscle contraction in generating movement? Options: A. It only generates opposing forces, B. It only generates stabilizing forces, C. It generates opposing and stabilizing forces, D. It has no role in generating movement Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the main difference between the somatic nervous system and the autonomic nervous system? Options: A. The somatic nervous system gives us almost complete control over our movements, while the autonomic nervous system manages our movements beyond our direct control, B. The somatic nervous system manages our movements beyond our direct control, while the autonomic nervous system gives us almost complete control over our movements, C. Both systems give us almost complete control over our movements, D. Both systems manage our movements beyond our direct control Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main byproduct of muscle contraction? Options: A. Heat, B. Movement, C. Force, D. Energy Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 10. 

The ground truth MCQ asks about the role of the muscular system in generating body heat, and Question 10 asks about the main byproduct of muscle contraction, which is heat. Although the questions are not identical, they are related in content and intent. The correct option for Question 10, "A. Heat", aligns with the correct option for the ground truth MCQ, "A. True", which states that the muscular system is responsible for generating most of the body heat.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 10

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the 1950s, a group of ranchers in Idaho were baffled when their sheep gave birth
to lambs with a singular deformity. Mystified by these cyclops sheep, they called in scientists from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture to investigate. The researchers hypothesized
that the pregnant ewes had snacked on poisonous 
birth defect-causing plants. They collected the local flora
and fed samples to lab rats, but struggled to replicate the effect. So they decided 
to directly observe the sheep with one scientist even living
with the herd for three summers. After a decade of trial and error,
the scientists finally found the culprit, wild corn lilies. The lilies contained an active molecule
with six connected rings that they named cyclopamine
in reference to the cyclops sheep. They didn't know exactly
how cyclopamine caused the defect but told ranchers to steer clear. It took about four decades before
a team of biologists, led by Professor Philip Beachy, stumbled upon the answer. His lab was studying a specific gene
found in many species, from mice to humans, called the hedgehog gene. It was named by two scientists, who later
shared the Noble Prize for their work, who found that mutating 
this gene in fruit flies produced pointy spikes like a hedgehog. Beachy and his colleagues performed
genetic modifications to turn off the hedgehog genes in mice. This resulted in severe defects 
in the development of their brains, organs, and eyes or, rather, eye. Then while perusing a textbook, Beachy 
came across photos of the cyclops sheep and realized what had eluded scientists
for four decades. Something must have gone awry 
involving the hedgehog gene. Let's take a step back. Genes contain instructions that tell
cells what to do and when to do it, and they communicate their directives
using proteins. The hedgehog gene itself tells cells
to release a so-called hedgehog protein, which kicks off a complex 
series of cellular signals. Here's how it works in normal
healthy development. Hedgehog protein latches on to
a protein called patched. That inhibits, or holds, patched back, allowing another protein called
smoothened to freely signal the cells, telling them where to go
and what kind of tissues to become. Cyclopamine, say in the form 
of a delicious corn lily, interrupts this pathway
by binding onto smoothened. That locks smoothened up so that
it's unable to send the signals needed to mold the brain 
into two hemispheres, and form fingers or separate eyes. So even though the hedgehog
protein is still doing its job of keeping the way clear for smoothened, cyclopamine blocks smoothened
from passing along its chemical message. That settled the science
behind the one-eyed sheep, but Beachy and his team 
caught the glimmer of another more beneficial connection. They noted that uncontrolled activation
of the smoothened protein was associated with a human syndrome. It's known as Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome,
and it predisposes people to certain cancers. The scientists proposed putting cyclopamine's smoothened 
binding powers to good use as a treatment for these cancers, as long as the patient wasn't pregnant. Unfortunately, researchers eventually
found that cyclopamine causes negative side effects, and its chemical properties
make it difficult to work with. But they did discover that closely
related molecules are safe and effective, and two of these drugs were approved
in 2012 and 2015 as skin cancer medicines. When those farmers first saw
the cyclops sheep, they could have chalked it up to
a freak genetic mutation and walked away. Instead, their decision to investigate
turned a mystery into medicine showing that sometimes
there's more than meets the eye.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Scientists discovered that the cyclops sheep deformity was caused by pregnant ewes eating:
Options: A. Grass, B. Berries, C. Wild corn lilies, D. Fruit flies
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the unusual condition affecting the sheep in Idaho in the 1950s? Options: A. A genetic mutation that caused them to have multiple limbs, B. A deformity that resulted in one eye per head, C. A disease that caused them to lose their fur, D. A condition that made them grow at an abnormal rate Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what was the name of the scientist who led the team that finally found the cause of the cyclops sheep condition? Options: A. Professor Philip Beachy, B. Dr. John Smith, C. Dr. Jane Doe, D. The U.S. Department of Agriculture team leader Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the name of the gene that, when mutated, can cause severe defects in the development of brains, organs, and eyes? Options: A. Hedgehog gene, B. Cyclopamine gene, C. Smoothened gene, D. Patched gene Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the role of the hedgehog protein in normal healthy development? Options: A. It inhibits the patched protein, B. It binds to the smoothened protein, C. It tells cells where to go and what kind of tissues to become, D. It has no role in development Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the effect of cyclopamine on the smoothened protein? Options: A. It activates the smoothened protein, B. It inhibits the smoothened protein, C. It locks up the smoothened protein so it cannot send signals, D. It has no effect on the smoothened protein Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the human syndrome associated with uncontrolled activation of the smoothened protein? Options: A. Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome, B. Cyclopamine Syndrome, C. Smoothened Syndrome, D. Hedgehog Syndrome Correct Option: A
Question 7: What was the outcome of the researchers' proposal to use cyclopamine as a treatment for Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome? Options: A. It was approved as a treatment, B. It was rejected as a treatment, C. It was found to have negative side effects and was difficult to work with, D. It had no effect on the syndrome Correct Option: C
Question 8: What did researchers discover as a result of studying closely related molecules to cyclopamine? Options: A. They found that they had no effect on Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome, B. They found that they had negative side effects, C. They found that they were safe and effective as treatments for skin cancer, D. They found that they had no role in development Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the outcome of the decision by the farmers to investigate the unusual condition affecting their sheep? Options: A. It was a waste of time and resources, B. It led to the discovery of a new disease, C. It turned a mystery into medicine, D. It had no effect on their sheep Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the main idea of the transcript? Options: A. The story of a group of sheep with a genetic mutation, B. The discovery of a new disease affecting sheep, C. The investigation of a mysterious condition affecting sheep and its connection to human health, D. The story of a group of scientists who studied sheep Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not explicitly present in the provided options. However, based on the content and intent, I would say that Question 1 is the closest match, but it doesn't exactly match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose the most similar one, I would say that Question 1 is the closest, but it's not a perfect match.

However, I can suggest a possible match if we rephrase the ground truth MCQ to match the generated MCQs. A possible match could be:

Question: What plant did scientists discover was the cause of the cyclops sheep deformity?
Options: A. Grass, B. Berries, C. Wild corn lilies, D. Fruit flies

In this case, the generated MCQ that most closely matches this rephrased ground truth MCQ is not present in the provided options.

But if I had to choose from the provided options, I would say that Question 1 is the closest match, but it's not a perfect match.

Options: A. The gene is only found in hedgehogs, B. Mutations in the gene caused spikes like a hedgehog to form on fruit flies’ bodies, C. Mutations in the gene caused spikes like a hedgehog to form on mice, D. The gene was first discovered in hedgehogs
Correct Option: B

to lambs with a singular deformity. Mystified by these cyclops sheep, they called in scientists from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture to investigate. The researchers hypothesized
that the pregnant ewes had snacked on poisonous

found in many species, from mice to humans, called the hedgehog gene. It was named by two scientists, who later

to release a so-called hedgehog protein, which kicks off a complex 
series of cellular signals. Here's how it works in normal
healthy development. Hedgehog protein latches on to
a protein called patched. That inhibits, or holds, patched back, allowing another protein called
smoothened to freely signal the cells, telling them where to go
and what kind of tissues to become. Cyclopamine, say in the form 
of a delicious corn lily, interrupts this pathway
by binding onto smoothened. That locks smoothened up so that
it's unable to send the signals needed to mold the brain 
into two hemispheres, and form fingers or separate eyes. So even though the hedgehog
protein is still doing its job of keeping the way clear for smoothened, cyclopamine blocks smoothened
from passing along its chemical message. That settled the science
behind the one-eyed sheep, but Beachy and his team 
caught the glimmer of another more beneficial connection. They noted that uncontrolled activation
of the smoothened protein was associated with a human syndrome. It's known as Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome,
and it predisposes people to certain cancers. The scientists proposed putting cyclopamine's smoothened 
binding powers to good use as a treatment for these cancers, as long as the patient wasn't pregnant. Unfortunately, researchers eventually
found that cyclopamine causes negative side effects, and its chemical properties
make it difficult to work with. But they did discover that closely
related molecules are safe and effective, and two of these drugs were approved
in 2012 and 2015 as skin cancer medicines. When those farmers first saw
the cyclops sheep, they could have chalked it up to
a freak genetic mutation and walked away. Instead, their decision to investigate
turned a mystery into medicine showing that sometimes
there's more than meets the eye.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In healthy cells, the hedgehog protein latches onto:
Options: A. The smoothened protein, B. The patched protein, C. Cyclopamine, D. The hedgehog gene
Correct Option: B

Question 5: What is the effect of cyclopamine on the smoothened protein? Options: A. It activates the smoothened protein, B. It inhibits the smoothened protein, C. It locks up the smoothened protein so it cannot send signals, D. It has no effect on the smoothened protein Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the 1950s, a group of ranchers in Idaho were baffled when their sheep gave birth
to lambs with a singular deformity. Mystified by these cyclops sheep, they called in scientists from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture to investigate. The researchers hypothesized
that the pregnant ewes had snacked on poisonous 
birth defect-causing plants. They collected the local flora
and fed samples to lab rats, but struggled to replicate the effect. So they decided 
to directly observe the sheep with one scientist even living
with the herd for three summers. After a decade of trial and error,
the scientists finally found the culprit, wild corn lilies. The lilies contained an active molecule
with six connected rings that they named cyclopamine
in reference to the cyclops sheep. They didn't know exactly
how cyclopamine caused the defect but told ranchers to steer clear. It took about four decades before
a team of biologists, led by Professor Philip Beachy, stumbled upon the answer. His lab was studying a specific gene
found in many species, from mice to humans, called the hedgehog gene. It was named by two scientists, who later
shared the Noble Prize for their work, who found that mutating 
this gene in fruit flies produced pointy spikes like a hedgehog. Beachy and his colleagues performed
genetic modifications to turn off the hedgehog genes in mice. This resulted in severe defects 
in the development of their brains, organs, and eyes or, rather, eye. Then while perusing a textbook, Beachy 
came across photos of the cyclops sheep and realized what had eluded scientists
for four decades. Something must have gone awry 
involving the hedgehog gene. Let's take a step back. Genes contain instructions that tell
cells what to do and when to do it, and they communicate their directives
using proteins. The hedgehog gene itself tells cells
to release a so-called hedgehog protein, which kicks off a complex 
series of cellular signals. Here's how it works in normal
healthy development. Hedgehog protein latches on to
a protein called patched. That inhibits, or holds, patched back, allowing another protein called
smoothened to freely signal the cells, telling them where to go
and what kind of tissues to become. Cyclopamine, say in the form 
of a delicious corn lily, interrupts this pathway
by binding onto smoothened. That locks smoothened up so that
it's unable to send the signals needed to mold the brain 
into two hemispheres, and form fingers or separate eyes. So even though the hedgehog
protein is still doing its job of keeping the way clear for smoothened, cyclopamine blocks smoothened
from passing along its chemical message. That settled the science
behind the one-eyed sheep, but Beachy and his team 
caught the glimmer of another more beneficial connection. They noted that uncontrolled activation
of the smoothened protein was associated with a human syndrome. It's known as Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome,
and it predisposes people to certain cancers. The scientists proposed putting cyclopamine's smoothened 
binding powers to good use as a treatment for these cancers, as long as the patient wasn't pregnant. Unfortunately, researchers eventually
found that cyclopamine causes negative side effects, and its chemical properties
make it difficult to work with. But they did discover that closely
related molecules are safe and effective, and two of these drugs were approved
in 2012 and 2015 as skin cancer medicines. When those farmers first saw
the cyclops sheep, they could have chalked it up to
a freak genetic mutation and walked away. Instead, their decision to investigate
turned a mystery into medicine showing that sometimes
there's more than meets the eye.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Scientists discovered that compounds related to cyclopamine could be used to treat what kind of cancer?
Options: A. Lung cancer, B. Brain cancer, C. Colon cancer, D. Skin cancer
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
They say the pen is mightier 
than the sword, and authorities have often agreed. From outlawed religious tracts
and revolutionary manifestos to censored and burned books, we know the potential power
of words to overturn the social order. But as strange as it may seem, some numbers have also been considered
dangerous enough to ban. Our distant ancestors long counted
objects using simple tally marks. But as they developed agriculture and
began living together in larger groups, this was no longer enough. As numbers grew more complex, people began not just using them,
but thinking about what they are and how they work. And by 600 B.C.E. in Ancient Greece,
the study of numbers was well-developed. The mathematician Pythagoras
and his school of followers found numerical patterns in shapes,
music, and the stars. For them, mathematics held 
the deepest secrets of the universe. But one Pythagorean named Hippasus
discovered something disturbing. Some quantities, like the diagonal
of a square with sides of length one couldn't be expressed by any combination
of whole numbers or fractions, no matter how small. These numbers, 
which we call irrational numbers, were perceived as a threat to the Pythagorean's notion 
of a perfect universe. They imagined a reality 
that could be described with rational, numerical patterns. Historians write that Hippasus
was exhiled for publicizing his findings, while legends claim he was drowned
as punishment from the gods. While irrational numbers 
upset philosophers, later mathematical inventions
would draw attention from political 
and religious authorities, as well. In the Middle Ages, while Europe
was still using Roman numerals, other cultures had developed 
positional systems that included a symbol for zero. When Arab travelers brought this system
to the bustling maritime cities of Italy, its advantages for merchants
and bankers was clear. But the authorities were more wary. Hindu-Arabic numerals were considered
easier to forge or alter, especially since they were less
familiar to customers than to merchants. And the concept of zero opened 
the door to negative numbers and the recording of debt at a time when moneylending
was regarded with suspicion. In the 13th century, Florence banned
the use of Hindu-Arabic numerals for record keeping. And though they soon proved
too useful to ignore, controversies over zero 
and negative numbers continued for a long time. Negative numbers 
were dismissed as absurd well into the 19th century. And prominent mathematicians,
like Gerolamo Cardano, avoided using zero, even though it would have made it
much easier to find solutions to cubic and the quartic equations. Even today it's illegal to use
some numbers for different reasons. Some are banned because
of what they represent. For example, governments
have prohibited the display of numbers that have symbolic meaning, such as the date of a revolution or connections to oppositional 
political figures or parties. Other numbers are potentially illegal
because of the information they carry. Just about any information, whether text, image, video, or executable programs can
be translated into a string of numbers. But this means that protected information, whether copyrights, proprietary materials, or state secrets can also be represented as numbers, so possessing or publishing these numbers
may be treated as a criminal offense. This idea gathered attention in 2001 when code that could be used
to decrypt DVDs was widely shared and distributed
in the form of a large prime number. The idea of illegal numbers 
may sound absurd, but like words, written numbers are a way
of expressing concepts and information. And in a world where calculations 
and algorithms shape more and more of our lives, the mathematician's pencil
grows stronger by the day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Our distant ancestors counted objects using:
Options: A. Tally marks, B. Roman numerals, C. Fingers and toes, D. Fractions
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:

The Ship of Theseus, C. The cogito, ergo sum, D. The thought experiment of imagining oneself as a brain in a vat Correct Option: C
Question 2: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what is the main idea behind the rubber hand illusion? Options: A. It's an experiment to prove the existence of the conscious mind, B. It's a trick to convince people that their body is not their own, C. It's an experiment to show that our bodies and external sensations are inseparable from our subjective consciousness, D. It's a way to measure the strength of a person's sense of self Correct Option: C
Question 3: **Application**: If we accept the idea that our bodies are part of our consciousness, how might this have implications for the development of future technologies such as neural prosthetics? Options: A. Yes, it might lead to a more integrated approach to designing these technologies, considering the interconnectedness of the body and mind, B. No, it has no bearing on the development of these technologies, C. It might lead to a more fragmented approach to designing these technologies, D. It might lead to a more abstract approach to designing these technologies Correct Option: A
Question 4: **Analysis**: According to the transcript, what is the main difference between the views of René Descartes and modern scientists on the relationship between the mind and body? Options: A. Descartes believes that the mind and body are connected, while modern scientists believe that they are separate, B. Descartes believes that the mind is a product of the body, while modern scientists believe that the body is a product of the mind, C. Descartes believes that the mind and body are separate, while modern scientists believe that they are connected, D. Descartes believes that the mind and body are identical, while modern scientists believe that they are distinct Correct Option: C
Question 5: **Synthesis**: If we combine the ideas of the rubber hand illusion and the concept of mind uploading, what might be the implications for our understanding of the self? Options: A. It might lead to a more fragmented understanding of the self, B. It might lead to a more integrated understanding of the self, considering the interconnectedness of the body and mind, C. It might lead to a more abstract understanding of the self, D. It might lead to a more concrete understanding of the self Correct Option: B
Question 6: **Evaluation**: Do you think that the idea of mind uploading is a viable solution to the problem of mortality? Options: A. Yes, it's a promising solution, B. No, it's not a viable solution, C. It's a complex issue that requires further consideration, considering the ethical and technological implications, D. It's not relevant to the problem of mortality Correct Option: C
Question 7: **Knowledge**: Who is the French priest and philosopher who claimed that when we think about reaching for a fork, it's actually God who moves our hand? Options: A. René Descartes, B. Nicolas Malebranche, C. George Berkeley, D. Aristotle Correct Option: B
Question 8: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what is the main idea behind the concept of the "immaterial soul"? Options: A. It's a concept that suggests that the soul is a separate entity from the body, B. It's a concept that suggests that the soul is a product of the body, C. It's a concept that suggests that the soul is a combination of the body and the mind, D. It's a concept that suggests that the soul is a separate entity from the mind Correct Option: A
Question 9: **Application**: If we accept the idea that our bodies are part of our consciousness, might this have implications for our understanding of the concept of self? Options: A. Yes, it might lead to a more integrated understanding of the self, considering the interconnectedness of the body and mind, B. No, it has no bearing on our understanding of the self, C. It might lead to a more abstract understanding of the self, D. It might lead to a more fragmented understanding of the self Correct Option: A
Question 10: **Evaluation**: Do you think that the concept of the "mind-body dichotomy" is a useful framework for understanding the relationship between the mind and body? Options: A. Yes, it's a useful framework, B. No, it's not a useful framework, C. It's a complex issue that requires further consideration, considering the nuances of the relationship between the mind and body, D. It's not relevant to the relationship between the mind and body Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
They say the pen is mightier 
than the sword, and authorities have often agreed. From outlawed religious tracts
and revolutionary manifestos to censored and burned books, we know the potential power
of words to overturn the social order. But as strange as it may seem, some numbers have also been considered
dangerous enough to ban. Our distant ancestors long counted
objects using simple tally marks. But as they developed agriculture and
began living together in larger groups, this was no longer enough. As numbers grew more complex, people began not just using them,
but thinking about what they are and how they work. And by 600 B.C.E. in Ancient Greece,
the study of numbers was well-developed. The mathematician Pythagoras
and his school of followers found numerical patterns in shapes,
music, and the stars. For them, mathematics held 
the deepest secrets of the universe. But one Pythagorean named Hippasus
discovered something disturbing. Some quantities, like the diagonal
of a square with sides of length one couldn't be expressed by any combination
of whole numbers or fractions, no matter how small. These numbers, 
which we call irrational numbers, were perceived as a threat to the Pythagorean's notion 
of a perfect universe. They imagined a reality 
that could be described with rational, numerical patterns. Historians write that Hippasus
was exhiled for publicizing his findings, while legends claim he was drowned
as punishment from the gods. While irrational numbers 
upset philosophers, later mathematical inventions
would draw attention from political 
and religious authorities, as well. In the Middle Ages, while Europe
was still using Roman numerals, other cultures had developed 
positional systems that included a symbol for zero. When Arab travelers brought this system
to the bustling maritime cities of Italy, its advantages for merchants
and bankers was clear. But the authorities were more wary. Hindu-Arabic numerals were considered
easier to forge or alter, especially since they were less
familiar to customers than to merchants. And the concept of zero opened 
the door to negative numbers and the recording of debt at a time when moneylending
was regarded with suspicion. In the 13th century, Florence banned
the use of Hindu-Arabic numerals for record keeping. And though they soon proved
too useful to ignore, controversies over zero 
and negative numbers continued for a long time. Negative numbers 
were dismissed as absurd well into the 19th century. And prominent mathematicians,
like Gerolamo Cardano, avoided using zero, even though it would have made it
much easier to find solutions to cubic and the quartic equations. Even today it's illegal to use
some numbers for different reasons. Some are banned because
of what they represent. For example, governments
have prohibited the display of numbers that have symbolic meaning, such as the date of a revolution or connections to oppositional 
political figures or parties. Other numbers are potentially illegal
because of the information they carry. Just about any information, whether text, image, video, or executable programs can
be translated into a string of numbers. But this means that protected information, whether copyrights, proprietary materials, or state secrets can also be represented as numbers, so possessing or publishing these numbers
may be treated as a criminal offense. This idea gathered attention in 2001 when code that could be used
to decrypt DVDs was widely shared and distributed
in the form of a large prime number. The idea of illegal numbers 
may sound absurd, but like words, written numbers are a way
of expressing concepts and information. And in a world where calculations 
and algorithms shape more and more of our lives, the mathematician's pencil
grows stronger by the day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who were the Pythagoreans?
Options: A. People who discovered and proved the Pythagorean theorem, B. Merchants and bankers who used Pythagoras’ mathematics, C. Mathematician-philosophers who were members of Pythagoras’ school, D. Ancient Greeks who studied mathematics
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge**: What is the name of the famous thought experiment used by René Descartes to prove the existence of the conscious mind? Options: A. The rubber hand illusion, B. The Ship of Theseus, C. The cogito, ergo sum, D. The thought experiment of imagining oneself as a brain in a vat Correct Option: C
Question 2: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what is the main idea behind the rubber hand illusion? Options: A. It's an experiment to prove the existence of the conscious mind, B. It's a trick to convince people that their body is not their own, C. It's an experiment to show that our bodies and external sensations are inseparable from our subjective consciousness, D. It's a way to measure the strength of a person's sense of self Correct Option: C
Question 3: **Application**: If we accept the idea that our bodies are part of our consciousness, how might this have implications for the development of future technologies such as neural prosthetics? Options: A. Yes, it might lead to a more integrated approach to designing these technologies, considering the interconnectedness of the body and mind, B. No, it has no bearing on the development of these technologies, C. It might lead to a more fragmented approach to designing these technologies, D. It might lead to a more abstract approach to designing these technologies Correct Option: A
Question 4: **Analysis**: According to the transcript, what is the main difference between the views of René Descartes and modern scientists on the relationship between the mind and body? Options: A. Descartes believes that the mind and body are connected, while modern scientists believe that they are separate, B. Descartes believes that the mind is a product of the body, while modern scientists believe that the body is a product of the mind, C. Descartes believes that the mind and body are separate, while modern scientists believe that they are connected, D. Descartes believes that the mind and body are identical, while modern scientists believe that they are distinct Correct Option: C
Question 5: **Synthesis**: If we combine the ideas of the rubber hand illusion and the concept of mind uploading, what might be the implications for our understanding of the self? Options: A. It might lead to a more fragmented understanding of the self, B. It might lead to a more integrated understanding of the self, considering the interconnectedness of the body and mind, C. It might lead to a more abstract understanding of the self, D. It might lead to a more concrete understanding of the self Correct Option: B
Question 6: **Evaluation**: Do you think that the idea of mind uploading is a viable solution to the problem of mortality? Options: A. Yes, it's a promising solution, B. No, it's not a viable solution, C. It's a complex issue that requires further consideration, considering the ethical and technological implications, D. It's not relevant to the problem of mortality Correct Option: C
Question 7: **Knowledge**: Who is the French priest and philosopher who claimed that when we think about reaching for a fork, it's actually God who moves our hand? Options: A. René Descartes, B. Nicolas Malebranche, C. George Berkeley, D. Aristotle Correct Option: B
Question 8: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what is the main idea behind the concept of the "immaterial soul"? Options: A. It's a concept that suggests that the soul is a separate entity from the body, B. It's a concept that suggests that the soul is a product of the body, C. It's a concept that suggests that the soul is a combination of the body and the mind, D. It's a concept that suggests that the soul is a separate entity from the mind Correct Option: A
Question 9: **Application**: If we accept the idea that our bodies are part of our consciousness, might this have implications for our understanding of the concept of self? Options: A. Yes, it might lead to a more integrated understanding of the self, considering the interconnectedness of the body and mind, B. No, it has no bearing on our understanding of the self, C. It might lead to a more abstract understanding of the self, D. It might lead to a more fragmented understanding of the self Correct Option: A
Question 10: **Evaluation**: Do you think that the concept of the "mind-body dichotomy" is a useful framework for understanding the relationship between the mind and body? Options: A. Yes, it's a useful framework, B. No, it's not a useful framework, C. It's a complex issue that requires further consideration, considering the nuances of the relationship between the mind and body, D. It's not relevant to the relationship between the mind and body Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
They say the pen is mightier 
than the sword, and authorities have often agreed. From outlawed religious tracts
and revolutionary manifestos to censored and burned books, we know the potential power
of words to overturn the social order. But as strange as it may seem, some numbers have also been considered
dangerous enough to ban. Our distant ancestors long counted
objects using simple tally marks. But as they developed agriculture and
began living together in larger groups, this was no longer enough. As numbers grew more complex, people began not just using them,
but thinking about what they are and how they work. And by 600 B.C.E. in Ancient Greece,
the study of numbers was well-developed. The mathematician Pythagoras
and his school of followers found numerical patterns in shapes,
music, and the stars. For them, mathematics held 
the deepest secrets of the universe. But one Pythagorean named Hippasus
discovered something disturbing. Some quantities, like the diagonal
of a square with sides of length one couldn't be expressed by any combination
of whole numbers or fractions, no matter how small. These numbers, 
which we call irrational numbers, were perceived as a threat to the Pythagorean's notion 
of a perfect universe. They imagined a reality 
that could be described with rational, numerical patterns. Historians write that Hippasus
was exhiled for publicizing his findings, while legends claim he was drowned
as punishment from the gods. While irrational numbers 
upset philosophers, later mathematical inventions
would draw attention from political 
and religious authorities, as well. In the Middle Ages, while Europe
was still using Roman numerals, other cultures had developed 
positional systems that included a symbol for zero. When Arab travelers brought this system
to the bustling maritime cities of Italy, its advantages for merchants
and bankers was clear. But the authorities were more wary. Hindu-Arabic numerals were considered
easier to forge or alter, especially since they were less
familiar to customers than to merchants. And the concept of zero opened 
the door to negative numbers and the recording of debt at a time when moneylending
was regarded with suspicion. In the 13th century, Florence banned
the use of Hindu-Arabic numerals for record keeping. And though they soon proved
too useful to ignore, controversies over zero 
and negative numbers continued for a long time. Negative numbers 
were dismissed as absurd well into the 19th century. And prominent mathematicians,
like Gerolamo Cardano, avoided using zero, even though it would have made it
much easier to find solutions to cubic and the quartic equations. Even today it's illegal to use
some numbers for different reasons. Some are banned because
of what they represent. For example, governments
have prohibited the display of numbers that have symbolic meaning, such as the date of a revolution or connections to oppositional 
political figures or parties. Other numbers are potentially illegal
because of the information they carry. Just about any information, whether text, image, video, or executable programs can
be translated into a string of numbers. But this means that protected information, whether copyrights, proprietary materials, or state secrets can also be represented as numbers, so possessing or publishing these numbers
may be treated as a criminal offense. This idea gathered attention in 2001 when code that could be used
to decrypt DVDs was widely shared and distributed
in the form of a large prime number. The idea of illegal numbers 
may sound absurd, but like words, written numbers are a way
of expressing concepts and information. And in a world where calculations 
and algorithms shape more and more of our lives, the mathematician's pencil
grows stronger by the day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why were Arabic numerals banned for record-keeping in Florence?
Options: A. Because they were unfamiliar to most people, B. Because they were not useful, C. Because they were illegible, D. Because they were regarded as easy to adjust fraudulently
Correct Option: D

It's a way to measure the strength of a person's sense of self Correct Option: C

No, it has no bearing on the development of these technologies, C. It might lead to a more fragmented approach to designing these technologies, D. It might lead to a more abstract approach to designing these technologies Correct Option: A

Descartes believes that the mind and body are connected, while modern scientists believe that they are separate, B. Descartes believes that the mind is a product of the body, while modern scientists believe that the body is a product of the mind, C. Descartes believes that the mind and body are separate, while modern scientists believe that they are connected, D. It might lead to a more fragmented understanding of the self, B. It might lead to a more integrated understanding of the self, considering the interconnectedness of the body and mind, C. It might lead to a more abstract understanding of the self, D. It might lead to a more concrete understanding of the self Correct Option: B

It's a concept that suggests that the soul is a combination of the body and the mind, D. It's a concept that suggests that the soul is a separate entity from the mind Correct Option: A

Yes, it's a useful framework, B. No, it's not a useful framework, C. It's a complex issue that requires further consideration, considering the nuances of the relationship between the mind and body, D. It's not relevant to the relationship between the mind and body Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
They say the pen is mightier 
than the sword, and authorities have often agreed. From outlawed religious tracts
and revolutionary manifestos to censored and burned books, we know the potential power
of words to overturn the social order. But as strange as it may seem, some numbers have also been considered
dangerous enough to ban. Our distant ancestors long counted
objects using simple tally marks. But as they developed agriculture and
began living together in larger groups, this was no longer enough. As numbers grew more complex, people began not just using them,
but thinking about what they are and how they work. And by 600 B.C.E. in Ancient Greece,
the study of numbers was well-developed. The mathematician Pythagoras
and his school of followers found numerical patterns in shapes,
music, and the stars. For them, mathematics held 
the deepest secrets of the universe. But one Pythagorean named Hippasus
discovered something disturbing. Some quantities, like the diagonal
of a square with sides of length one couldn't be expressed by any combination
of whole numbers or fractions, no matter how small. These numbers, 
which we call irrational numbers, were perceived as a threat to the Pythagorean's notion 
of a perfect universe. They imagined a reality 
that could be described with rational, numerical patterns. Historians write that Hippasus
was exhiled for publicizing his findings, while legends claim he was drowned
as punishment from the gods. While irrational numbers 
upset philosophers, later mathematical inventions
would draw attention from political 
and religious authorities, as well. In the Middle Ages, while Europe
was still using Roman numerals, other cultures had developed 
positional systems that included a symbol for zero. When Arab travelers brought this system
to the bustling maritime cities of Italy, its advantages for merchants
and bankers was clear. But the authorities were more wary. Hindu-Arabic numerals were considered
easier to forge or alter, especially since they were less
familiar to customers than to merchants. And the concept of zero opened 
the door to negative numbers and the recording of debt at a time when moneylending
was regarded with suspicion. In the 13th century, Florence banned
the use of Hindu-Arabic numerals for record keeping. And though they soon proved
too useful to ignore, controversies over zero 
and negative numbers continued for a long time. Negative numbers 
were dismissed as absurd well into the 19th century. And prominent mathematicians,
like Gerolamo Cardano, avoided using zero, even though it would have made it
much easier to find solutions to cubic and the quartic equations. Even today it's illegal to use
some numbers for different reasons. Some are banned because
of what they represent. For example, governments
have prohibited the display of numbers that have symbolic meaning, such as the date of a revolution or connections to oppositional 
political figures or parties. Other numbers are potentially illegal
because of the information they carry. Just about any information, whether text, image, video, or executable programs can
be translated into a string of numbers. But this means that protected information, whether copyrights, proprietary materials, or state secrets can also be represented as numbers, so possessing or publishing these numbers
may be treated as a criminal offense. This idea gathered attention in 2001 when code that could be used
to decrypt DVDs was widely shared and distributed
in the form of a large prime number. The idea of illegal numbers 
may sound absurd, but like words, written numbers are a way
of expressing concepts and information. And in a world where calculations 
and algorithms shape more and more of our lives, the mathematician's pencil
grows stronger by the day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why today it is illegal to use some numbers in some countries?
Options: A. Because they may have symbolic meaning, B. Because they carry copyrighted information, C. Because they carry otherwise protected information, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Look at your hand. How do you know it's really yours? It seems obvious, unless you've
experienced the rubber hand illusion. In this experiment, a dummy hand is placed
in front of you and your real hand is hidden
behind a screen. Both are simultaneously stroked
with a paint brush. No matter how much you remind yourself
the dummy hand isn't yours, you eventually start to feel like it is, and inevitably flinch
when it's threatened with a knife. That may just be a temporary trick,
but it speaks to a larger truth: our bodies, the physical, 
biological parts of us, and our minds, the thinking,
conscious aspects, have a complicated, tangled relationship. Which one primarily defines you
or your self? Are you a physical body that only
experiences thoughts and emotions as a result of biochemical interactions
in the brain? That would be a body with a mind. Or is there some non-physical part of you
that's pulling the strings but could live outside 
of your biological body? That would be a mind with a body. That takes us to an old question of whether the body 
and mind are two separate things. In a famous thought experiment, 16th-century philosopher 
René Descartes pointed out that even if all our physical sensations
were just a hallucinatory dream, our mind and thoughts 
would still be there. That, for him, was the ultimate proof
of our existence. And it led him to conclude that the conscious mind is something separate
from the material body that forms the core of our identity. The notion of a non-physical consciousness echoes the belief of many religions
in an immaterial soul for which the body is only 
a temporary shell. If we accept this, 
another problem emerges. How can a non-physical mind have
any interaction with the physical body? If the mind has no shape, 
weight, or motion, how can it move your muscles? Or if we assume it can, why can your mind
only move your body and not others? Some thinkers have found creative ways
to get around this dilemma. For example, the French priest 
and philosopher Nicolas Malebranche claimed that when we think about
reaching for a fork, it's actually god who moves our hand. Another priest philosopher 
named George Berkeley concluded that the material world
is an illusion, existing only as mental perceptions. This question of mind versus body
isn't just the domain of philosophers. With the development of psychology
and neuroscience, scientists have weighed in, as well. Many modern scientists reject the idea that there's any distinction 
between the mind and body. Neuroscience suggests that our bodies,
along with their physical senses, are deeply integrated 
with the activity in our brains to form what we call consciousness. From the day we're born, our mental development is formed
through our body's interaction with the external world. Every sight, sound, and touch create
new maps and representations in the brain that eventually become responsible
for regulating our experience of self. And we have other senses,
besides the typical five, such as the sense of balance and a sense of the relative location
of our body parts. The rubber hand illusion,
and similar virtual reality experiments, show that our senses can easily
mislead us in our judgment of self. They also suggest that our bodies
and external sensations are inseparable from 
our subjective consciousness. If this is true, then perhaps Descartes'
experiment was mistaken from the start. After all, if we close our eyes
in a silent room, the feeling of having a body
isn't something we can just imagine away. This question of mind and body
becomes particularly interesting at a time when we're considering
future technologies, such as neural prosthetics
and wearable robots that could become extended parts
of our bodies. Or the slightly more radical idea
of mind uploading, which dangles the possibility 
of immortal life without a body by transferring a human consciousness
into a computer. If the body is deeply mapped
in the brain, then by extending our sense of self
to new wearable devices, our brains may eventually adapt
to a restructured version with new sensory representations. Or perhaps uploading our consciousness
into a computer might not even be possible unless we can also simulate a body
capable of delivering physical sensations. The idea that our bodies are part
of our consciousness and vice versa also isn't new. It's found extensively 
in Buddhist thought, as well as the writings of philosophers
from Heidegger to Aristotle. But for now, we're still left
with the open question of what exactly our self is. Are we a mind equipped with
a physical body as Descartes suggested? Or a complex organism 
that's gained consciousness over millions of years of evolution thanks to a bigger brain and
more neurons than our distant ancestors? Or something else entirely that
no one's yet dreamt up?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the rubber hand illusion, the dummy hand feels like the viewer’s real hand because of the synchronization between two sensory inputs from both hands. What are those two sensory inputs?
Options: A. Touch and sound, B. Touch and vision, C. Vision and pain, D. Vision and proprioception
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where were the first standardized tests administered over 2,000 years ago? Options: A. Ancient Greece, B. China during the Han dynasty, C. Rome, D. Egypt Correct Option: B

Question 3: How can a standardized test be used to measure a student's performance? Options: A. By comparing their results to those of other students, B. By evaluating their performance against set criteria, C. By measuring their results only, D. By assessing their physical abilities Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is a percentile? Options: A. A measure of a student's overall performance, B. A measure of a student's performance compared to others, C. A measure of a student's creativity, D. A measure of a student's physical abilities Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why are standardized tests sometimes controversial? Options: A. Because they are too easy, B. Because they are too hard, C. Because they can result in sweeping and often negative changes for test takers, D. Because they are not relevant to real-life situations Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the main difference between reliability and validity in standardized tests? Options: A. Reliability measures a student's performance, while validity measures a teacher's performance, B. Reliability measures a student's performance consistently, while validity measures a student's performance accurately, C. Reliability measures a student's creativity, while validity measures a student's physical abilities, D. Reliability measures a student's physical abilities, while validity measures a student's creativity Correct Option: B

Question 8: What is the purpose of a ruler in the context of standardized tests? Options: A. To measure a student's creativity, B. To measure a student's physical abilities, C. To measure a student's performance consistently, D. To measure a student's performance accurately Correct Option: D
Question 9: Why is it important to use standardized tests for the right jobs and to interpret results appropriately? Options: A. Because it can result in sweeping and often negative changes for test takers, B. Because it can help us learn a little about a lot of people in a short time, C. Because it can tell us a lot about a single person, D. Because it is not relevant to real-life situations Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main idea of the transcript? Options: A. Standardized tests are not useful, B. Standardized tests are too hard, C. Standardized tests can be useful tools, but they need to be used correctly and interpreted appropriately, D. Standardized tests are not relevant to real-life situations Correct Option: C
Question 11: What are two critical ideas for understanding standardized tests? Options: A. Reliability and validity, B. Creativity and physical abilities, C. Accuracy and consistency, D. Validity and relevance Correct Option: A
Question 12: Why can't standardized tests alone tell us how smart someone is, how diplomats will handle a tough situation, or how brave a firefighter might turn out to be? Options: A. Because they are too easy, B. Because they are too hard, C. Because they are not designed to measure these abstract characteristics or skills, D. Because they are not relevant to real-life situations Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Look at your hand. How do you know it's really yours? It seems obvious, unless you've
experienced the rubber hand illusion. In this experiment, a dummy hand is placed
in front of you and your real hand is hidden
behind a screen. Both are simultaneously stroked
with a paint brush. No matter how much you remind yourself
the dummy hand isn't yours, you eventually start to feel like it is, and inevitably flinch
when it's threatened with a knife. That may just be a temporary trick,
but it speaks to a larger truth: our bodies, the physical, 
biological parts of us, and our minds, the thinking,
conscious aspects, have a complicated, tangled relationship. Which one primarily defines you
or your self? Are you a physical body that only
experiences thoughts and emotions as a result of biochemical interactions
in the brain? That would be a body with a mind. Or is there some non-physical part of you
that's pulling the strings but could live outside 
of your biological body? That would be a mind with a body. That takes us to an old question of whether the body 
and mind are two separate things. In a famous thought experiment, 16th-century philosopher 
René Descartes pointed out that even if all our physical sensations
were just a hallucinatory dream, our mind and thoughts 
would still be there. That, for him, was the ultimate proof
of our existence. And it led him to conclude that the conscious mind is something separate
from the material body that forms the core of our identity. The notion of a non-physical consciousness echoes the belief of many religions
in an immaterial soul for which the body is only 
a temporary shell. If we accept this, 
another problem emerges. How can a non-physical mind have
any interaction with the physical body? If the mind has no shape, 
weight, or motion, how can it move your muscles? Or if we assume it can, why can your mind
only move your body and not others? Some thinkers have found creative ways
to get around this dilemma. For example, the French priest 
and philosopher Nicolas Malebranche claimed that when we think about
reaching for a fork, it's actually god who moves our hand. Another priest philosopher 
named George Berkeley concluded that the material world
is an illusion, existing only as mental perceptions. This question of mind versus body
isn't just the domain of philosophers. With the development of psychology
and neuroscience, scientists have weighed in, as well. Many modern scientists reject the idea that there's any distinction 
between the mind and body. Neuroscience suggests that our bodies,
along with their physical senses, are deeply integrated 
with the activity in our brains to form what we call consciousness. From the day we're born, our mental development is formed
through our body's interaction with the external world. Every sight, sound, and touch create
new maps and representations in the brain that eventually become responsible
for regulating our experience of self. And we have other senses,
besides the typical five, such as the sense of balance and a sense of the relative location
of our body parts. The rubber hand illusion,
and similar virtual reality experiments, show that our senses can easily
mislead us in our judgment of self. They also suggest that our bodies
and external sensations are inseparable from 
our subjective consciousness. If this is true, then perhaps Descartes'
experiment was mistaken from the start. After all, if we close our eyes
in a silent room, the feeling of having a body
isn't something we can just imagine away. This question of mind and body
becomes particularly interesting at a time when we're considering
future technologies, such as neural prosthetics
and wearable robots that could become extended parts
of our bodies. Or the slightly more radical idea
of mind uploading, which dangles the possibility 
of immortal life without a body by transferring a human consciousness
into a computer. If the body is deeply mapped
in the brain, then by extending our sense of self
to new wearable devices, our brains may eventually adapt
to a restructured version with new sensory representations. Or perhaps uploading our consciousness
into a computer might not even be possible unless we can also simulate a body
capable of delivering physical sensations. The idea that our bodies are part
of our consciousness and vice versa also isn't new. It's found extensively 
in Buddhist thought, as well as the writings of philosophers
from Heidegger to Aristotle. But for now, we're still left
with the open question of what exactly our self is. Are we a mind equipped with
a physical body as Descartes suggested? Or a complex organism 
that's gained consciousness over millions of years of evolution thanks to a bigger brain and
more neurons than our distant ancestors? Or something else entirely that
no one's yet dreamt up?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Sixteenth-century philosopher René Descartes believed that the mind is something separate from the body because:
Options: A. The material world is an illusion existing only as mental perceptions, B. The existence of anything that we perceive from our senses can fundamentally be questioned, C. Even if we assume that our body is an illusion, our thoughts are still there and that is the ultimate proof of our existence, D. God is moving our bodies and God is immaterial
Correct Option: C

By evaluating their performance against set criteria, C. By measuring their results only, D. By assessing their physical abilities Correct Option: B

Question 5: Why are standardized tests sometimes controversial? Options: A. Because they are too easy, B. Because they are too hard, C. Because they can result in sweeping and often negative changes for test takers, D. Because they are not relevant to real-life situations Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the main difference between reliability and validity in standardized tests? Options: A. Reliability measures a student's performance, while validity measures a teacher's performance, B. Reliability measures a student's performance consistently, while validity measures a student's performance accurately, C. Reliability measures a student's creativity, while validity measures a student's physical abilities, D. Reliability measures a student's physical abilities, while validity measures a student's creativity Correct Option: B
Question 7: Why can standardized tests have a hard time measuring abstract characteristics or skills? Options: A. Because they are too easy, B. Because they are too hard, C. Because it can result in sweeping and often negative changes for test takers, B. Because it can help us learn a little about a lot of people in a short time, C. Because it can tell us a lot about a single person, D. Because it is not relevant to real-life situations Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main idea of the transcript? Options: A. Standardized tests are not useful, B. Standardized tests are too hard, C. Standardized tests can be useful tools, but they need to be used correctly and interpreted appropriately, D. Standardized tests are not relevant to real-life situations Correct Option: C
Question 11: What are two critical ideas for understanding standardized tests? Options: A. Reliability and validity, B. Creativity and physical abilities, C. Accuracy and consistency, D. Validity and relevance Correct Option: A
Question 12: Why can't standardized tests alone tell us how smart someone is, how diplomats will handle a tough situation, or how brave a firefighter might turn out to be? Options: A. Because they are too easy, B. Because they are too hard, C. Because they are not designed to measure these abstract characteristics or skills, D. Because they are not relevant to real-life situations Correct Option: C

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What can we learn from rubber hand illusion or other virtual reality experiments?
Options: A. Our senses can easily mislead us in our judgment of self, B. Our bodies are inseparable from our subjective consciousness, C. Our bodies and minds have a complicated tangled relationship, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D
