Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Every year, about 1,000 new words are
added to the Oxford English Dictionary. Where do they come from, and how do they make it 
into our everyday lives? With over 170,000 words currently in use
in the English language, it might seem we already have plenty. Yet, as our world changes, new ideas and inventions spring forth, and science progresses, our existing words leave gaps
in what we want to express and we fill those gaps 
in several ingenious, practical, and occasionally peculiar ways. One way is to absorb a word
from another language. English has borrowed so many words
over its history that nearly half of its vocabulary 
comes directly from other languages. Sometimes, this is simply because
the thing the word describes was borrowed itself. Rome and France brought legal
and religious concepts, like altar and jury, to Medieval England, while trade brought crops and cuisine, like Arabic coffee, Italian spaghetti, and Indian curry. But sometimes, another language 
has just the right word for a complex idea or emotion, like naïveté machismo, or schadenfreude. Scientists also use classical languages
to name new concepts. Clone, for example, was derived from
the Ancient Greek word for twig to describe creating a new plant
from a piece of the old. And today, the process works both ways, with English lending words like software
to languages all over the world. Another popular way 
to fill a vocabulary gap is by combining existing words that each
convey part of the new concept. This can be done by combining two
whole words into a compound word, like airport or starfish, or by clipping and blending parts of words
together, like spork, brunch, or internet. And unlike borrowings 
from other languages, these can often be understood
the first time you hear them. And sometimes a new word isn't new at all. Obsolete words gain new life by adopting
new meanings. Villain originally meant a peasant farmer,
but in a twist of aristocratic snobbery came to mean someone not bound
by the knightly code of chivalry and, therefore, a bad person. A geek went from 
being a carnival performer to any strange person to a specific type of awkward genius. And other times, words come to mean
their opposite through irony, metaphor, or misuse, like when sick or wicked are used
to describe something literally amazing. But if words can be formed 
in all these ways, why do some become mainstream
while others fall out of use or never catch on in the first place? Sometimes, the answer is simple, as when scientists or companies 
give an official name to a new discovery or technology. And some countries have language academies
to make the decisions. But for the most part, official sources
like dictionaries only document current usage. New words don't originate from above,
but from ordinary people spreading words that 
hit the right combination of useful and catchy. Take the word meme, coined in the 1970s 
by sociobiologist Richard Dawkins from the Ancient Greek for imitation. He used it to describe how ideas
and symbols propagate through a culture like genes through a population. With the advent of the Internet, the process became directly observable
in how jokes and images were popularized at lightning speed. And soon, the word came to refer
to a certain kind of image. So meme not only describes how words
become part of language, the word is a meme itself. And there's a word for this phenomenon
of words that describe themselves: autological. Not all new words are created equal. Some stick around for millennia, some adapt to changing times, and others die off. Some relay information, some interpret it, but the way these words are created and the journey they take to become
part of our speech tells us a lot about our world
and how we communicate within it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The word meme came about through:
Options: A. Analogy with the word gene, B. Borrowing from another language, C. A dictionary look-up process, D. Speculation
Correct Option: A

**Transcript**:
Every year, about 1,000 new words are
added to the Oxford English Dictionary. Where do they come from, and how do they make it 
into our everyday lives? With over 170,000 words currently in use
in the English language, it might seem we already have plenty. Yet, as our world changes, new ideas and inventions spring forth, and science progresses, our existing words leave gaps
in what we want to express and we fill those gaps 
in several ingenious, practical, and occasionally peculiar ways. One way is to absorb a word
from another language. English has borrowed so many words
over its history that nearly half of its vocabulary 
comes directly from other languages. Sometimes, this is simply because
the thing the word describes was borrowed itself. Rome and France brought legal
and religious concepts, like altar and jury, to Medieval England, while trade brought crops and cuisine, like Arabic coffee, Italian spaghetti, and Indian curry. But sometimes, another language 
has just the right word for a complex idea or emotion, like naïveté machismo, or schadenfreude. Scientists also use classical languages
to name new concepts. Clone, for example, was derived from
the Ancient Greek word for twig to describe creating a new plant
from a piece of the old. And today, the process works both ways, with English lending words like software
to languages all over the world. Another popular way 
to fill a vocabulary gap is by combining existing words that each
convey part of the new concept. This can be done by combining two
whole words into a compound word, like airport or starfish, or by clipping and blending parts of words
together, like spork, brunch, or internet. And unlike borrowings 
from other languages, these can often be understood
the first time you hear them. And sometimes a new word isn't new at all. Obsolete words gain new life by adopting
new meanings. Villain originally meant a peasant farmer,
but in a twist of aristocratic snobbery came to mean someone not bound
by the knightly code of chivalry and, therefore, a bad person. A geek went from 
being a carnival performer to any strange person to a specific type of awkward genius. And other times, words come to mean
their opposite through irony, metaphor, or misuse, like when sick or wicked are used
to describe something literally amazing. But if words can be formed 
in all these ways, why do some become mainstream
while others fall out of use or never catch on in the first place? Sometimes, the answer is simple, as when scientists or companies 
give an official name to a new discovery or technology. And some countries have language academies
to make the decisions. But for the most part, official sources
like dictionaries only document current usage. New words don't originate from above,
but from ordinary people spreading words that 
hit the right combination of useful and catchy. Take the word meme, coined in the 1970s 
by sociobiologist Richard Dawkins from the Ancient Greek for imitation. He used it to describe how ideas
and symbols propagate through a culture like genes through a population. With the advent of the Internet, the process became directly observable
in how jokes and images were popularized at lightning speed. And soon, the word came to refer
to a certain kind of image. So meme not only describes how words
become part of language, the word is a meme itself. And there's a word for this phenomenon
of words that describe themselves: autological. Not all new words are created equal. Some stick around for millennia, some adapt to changing times, and others die off. Some relay information, some interpret it, but the way these words are created and the journey they take to become
part of our speech tells us a lot about our world
and how we communicate within it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Obsolete words can gain new life:
Options: A. Because of nostalgia, B. Through a whim, C. By legislation, D. By giving them new meanings
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider the classic white t-shirt. Annually, we sell and buy
two billion t-shirts globally, making it one of the most common
garments in the world. But how and where is the average
t-shirt made, and what's its environmental impact? Clothing items can vary a lot, but a typical t-shirt begins its life
on a farm in America, China, or India where cotton seeds are sown, irrigated and
grown for the fluffy bolls they produce. Self-driving machines carefully harvest
these puffs, an industrial cotton gin mechanically
separates the fluffy bolls from the seeds, and the cotton lint is pressed 
into 225-kilogram bales. The cotton plants require a huge quantity
of water and pesticides. 2,700 liters of water are needed to produce
the average t-shirt, enough to fill more than 30 bathtubs. Meanwhile, cotton uses more insecticides
and pesticides than any other crop in the world. These pollutants can be carcinogenic, harm the health of field workers, and damage surrounding ecosystems. Some t-shirts are made of organic cotton
grown without pesticides and insecticides, but organic cotton makes up less than 1% of the 22.7 million metric tons 
of cotton produced worldwide. Once the cotton bales leave the farm, textile mills ship them
to a spinning facility, usually in China or India, where high-tech machines blend, card, comb, pull, stretch, and, finally, twist the cotton into
snowy ropes of yarn called slivers. Then, yarns are sent to the mill, where huge circular knitting machines weave them into sheets 
of rough grayish fabric treated with heat and chemicals
until they turn soft and white. Here, the fabric is dipped into
commercial bleaches and azo dyes, which make up the vivid coloring
in about 70% of textiles. Unfortunately, some of these contain
cancer-causing cadmium, lead, chromium, and mercury. Other harmful compounds and chemicals
can cause widespread contamination when released as toxic waste water
in rivers and oceans. Technologies are now so advanced
in some countries that the entire process of growing
and producing fabric barely touches a human hand. But only up until this point. After the finished cloth 
travels to factories, often in Bangladesh, China, India,
or Turkey, human labor is still required 
to stitch them up into t-shirts, intricate work that 
machines just can't do. This process has its own problems. Bangladesh, for example, which has surpassed China as the world's
biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts, employs 4.5 million people
in the t-shirt industry, but they typically face poor conditions
and low wages. After manufacture, all those t-shirts
travel by ship, train, and truck to be sold in high-income countries, a process that gives cotton 
an enormous carbon footprint. Some countries produce 
their own clothing domestically, which cuts out this polluting stage, but generally, apparel production accounts
for 10% of global carbon emissions. And it's escalating. Cheaper garments and the public's
willingness to buy boosted global production 
from 1994 to 2014 by 400% to around 80 billion garments each year. Finally, in a consumer's home, the t-shirt goes through one of the most
resource-intensive phases of its lifetime. In America, for instance, the average household does nearly
400 loads of laundry per year each using about 40 gallons of water. Washing machines and dryers 
both use energy, with dryers requiring five to six times
more than washers. This dramatic shift in clothing 
consumption over the last 20 years, driven by large corporations
and the trend of fast fashion has cost the environment, the health of farmers, and driven questionable 
human labor practices. It's also turned fashion into the second
largest polluter in the world after oil. But there are things we can do. Consider shopping secondhand. Try to look for textiles made from
recycled or organic fabrics. Wash clothes less and line dry
to save resources. Instead of throwing them away
at the end of their life, donate, recycle, or reuse them
as cleaning rags. And, finally, you might ask yourself, how many t-shirts and articles of clothing
will you consume over your lifetime, and what will be their combined 
impact on the world?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where in the world is cotton commonly grown?
Options: A. India, B. China, C. America, D. A and b only, E. All of the above
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the common myth about the brain's left and right sides that is unsupported by scientific evidence? Options: A. The left side controls emotions and the right side controls creativity., B. The left side controls movement and the right side controls sight., C. The left side controls language and the right side controls creativity., D. The left side controls logic and the right side controls creativity. Correct Option: D
Question 2: What theory suggests that the crossing over of visual fields in the brain gave animals a survival advantage? Options: A. The Broca-Wernicke theory, B. The theory of quick reflexes, C. The theory of complex nervous systems, D. The theory of predator avoidance Correct Option: C
Question 3: What happens when an animal sees a predator coming from its left side? Options: A. It turns left to escape., B. It turns right to escape., C. It stays still., D. It attacks the predator. Correct Option: B
Question 4: Who were the neurologists who first suggested that language is controlled by the left side of the brain? Options: A. Broca and Wernicke, B. Robert Louis Stevenson and Dr. Jekyll, C. The authors of the transcript, D. The researchers who studied the brain's left and right sides Correct Option: A
Question 5: What happens when a patient is missing a hemisphere or has their two hemispheres separated? Options: A. They show a complete range of behaviors, both logical and creative., B. They show only logical behaviors., C. They show only creative behaviors., D. They show no behaviors at all. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the main idea of the transcript? Options: A. The left side of the brain controls logic and the right side controls creativity., B. The brain's left and right sides are separate and distinct., C. The brain's left and right sides work together to control various functions, and there is no evidence to support the idea of a left-right split between logic and creativity., D. The brain's left and right sides are not important for controlling functions. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between logic and creativity? Options: A. They are at odds with each other., B. They are separate and distinct., C. They are interconnected and interdependent., D. They are not related. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the significance of the crossing over of visual fields in the brain? Options: A. It allows animals to see the world in a more complex way., B. It allows animals to move their eyes independently., C. It gives animals a survival advantage by allowing them to react quickly to predators., D. It has no significance for animal behavior. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the relationship between language and the brain's left side? Options: A. Language is controlled by the left side of the brain., B. Language is controlled by the right side of the brain., C. Language is controlled by both sides of the brain., D. Language is not controlled by the brain at all. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main takeaway from the transcript about the brain's left and right sides? Options: A. The left side of the brain controls logic and the right side controls creativity., B. The brain's left and right sides are separate and distinct., C. The brain's left and right sides work together to control various functions, and there is no evidence to support the idea of a left-right split between logic and creativity., D. The brain's left and right sides are not important for controlling functions. Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

or Turkey, human labor is still required 
to stitch them up into t-shirts, intricate work that

biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts, employs 4.5 million people
in the t-shirt industry, but they typically face poor conditions
and low wages. After manufacture, all those t-shirts
travel by ship, train, and truck to be sold in high-income countries, a process that gives cotton 
an enormous carbon footprint. Some countries produce 
their own clothing domestically, which cuts out this polluting stage, but generally, apparel production accounts
for 10% of global carbon emissions. And it's escalating. Cheaper garments and the public's
willingness to buy boosted global production 
from 1994 to 2014 by 400% to around 80 billion garments each year. Finally, in a consumer's home, the t-shirt goes through one of the most
resource-intensive phases of its lifetime. In America, for instance, the average household does nearly
400 loads of laundry per year each using about 40 gallons of water. Washing machines and dryers 
both use energy, with dryers requiring five to six times
more than washers. This dramatic shift in clothing 
consumption over the last 20 years, driven by large corporations
and the trend of fast fashion has cost the environment, the health of farmers, and driven questionable 
human labor practices. It's also turned fashion into the second
largest polluter in the world after oil. But there are things we can do. Consider shopping secondhand. Try to look for textiles made from
recycled or organic fabrics. Wash clothes less and line dry
to save resources. Instead of throwing them away
at the end of their life, donate, recycle, or reuse them
as cleaning rags. And, finally, you might ask yourself, how many t-shirts and articles of clothing
will you consume over your lifetime, and what will be their combined 
impact on the world?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: To produce the average t-shirt takes:
Options: A. 225 kg of cotton, B. Large amounts of pesticides, C. 2700 liters of water, D. C only, E. Both B and C
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the common myth about the brain's left and right sides that is unsupported by scientific evidence? Options: A. The left side controls emotions and the right side controls creativity., B. The left side controls movement and the right side controls sight., C. The left side controls language and the right side controls creativity., D. The left side controls logic and the right side controls creativity. Correct Option: D
Question 2: What theory suggests that the crossing over of visual fields in the brain gave animals a survival advantage? Options: A. The Broca-Wernicke theory, B. The theory of quick reflexes, C. The theory of complex nervous systems, D. The theory of predator avoidance Correct Option: C
Question 3: What happens when an animal sees a predator coming from its left side? Options: A. It turns left to escape., B. It turns right to escape., C. It stays still., D. It attacks the predator. Correct Option: B

The authors of the transcript, D. The researchers who studied the brain's left and right sides Correct Option: A

They show only logical behaviors., C. They show only creative behaviors., D. They show no behaviors at all. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the main idea of the transcript? Options: A. The left side of the brain controls logic and the right side controls creativity., B. The brain's left and right sides are separate and distinct., C. The brain's left and right sides work together to control various functions, and there is no evidence to support the idea of a left-right split between logic and creativity., D. The brain's left and right sides are not important for controlling functions. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between logic and creativity? Options: A. They are at odds with each other., B. They are separate and distinct., C. They are interconnected and interdependent., D. They are not related. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the significance of the crossing over of visual fields in the brain? Options: A. It allows animals to see the world in a more complex way., B. It allows animals to move their eyes independently., C. It gives animals a survival advantage by allowing them to react quickly to predators., D. It has no significance for animal behavior. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the relationship between language and the brain's left side? Options: A. Language is controlled by the left side of the brain., B. Language is controlled by the right side of the brain., C. Language is controlled by both sides of the brain., D. Language is not controlled by the brain at all. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main takeaway from the transcript about the brain's left and right sides? Options: A. The left side of the brain controls logic and the right side controls creativity., B. The brain's left and right sides are separate and distinct., C. The brain's left and right sides work together to control various functions, and there is no evidence to support the idea of a left-right split between logic and creativity., D. The brain's left and right sides are not important for controlling functions. Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider the classic white t-shirt. Annually, we sell and buy
two billion t-shirts globally, making it one of the most common
garments in the world. But how and where is the average
t-shirt made, and what's its environmental impact? Clothing items can vary a lot, but a typical t-shirt begins its life
on a farm in America, China, or India where cotton seeds are sown, irrigated and
grown for the fluffy bolls they produce. Self-driving machines carefully harvest
these puffs, an industrial cotton gin mechanically
separates the fluffy bolls from the seeds, and the cotton lint is pressed 
into 225-kilogram bales. The cotton plants require a huge quantity
of water and pesticides. 2,700 liters of water are needed to produce
the average t-shirt, enough to fill more than 30 bathtubs. Meanwhile, cotton uses more insecticides
and pesticides than any other crop in the world. These pollutants can be carcinogenic, harm the health of field workers, and damage surrounding ecosystems. Some t-shirts are made of organic cotton
grown without pesticides and insecticides, but organic cotton makes up less than 1% of the 22.7 million metric tons 
of cotton produced worldwide. Once the cotton bales leave the farm, textile mills ship them
to a spinning facility, usually in China or India, where high-tech machines blend, card, comb, pull, stretch, and, finally, twist the cotton into
snowy ropes of yarn called slivers. Then, yarns are sent to the mill, where huge circular knitting machines weave them into sheets 
of rough grayish fabric treated with heat and chemicals
until they turn soft and white. Here, the fabric is dipped into
commercial bleaches and azo dyes, which make up the vivid coloring
in about 70% of textiles. Unfortunately, some of these contain
cancer-causing cadmium, lead, chromium, and mercury. Other harmful compounds and chemicals
can cause widespread contamination when released as toxic waste water
in rivers and oceans. Technologies are now so advanced
in some countries that the entire process of growing
and producing fabric barely touches a human hand. But only up until this point. After the finished cloth 
travels to factories, often in Bangladesh, China, India,
or Turkey, human labor is still required 
to stitch them up into t-shirts, intricate work that 
machines just can't do. This process has its own problems. Bangladesh, for example, which has surpassed China as the world's
biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts, employs 4.5 million people
in the t-shirt industry, but they typically face poor conditions
and low wages. After manufacture, all those t-shirts
travel by ship, train, and truck to be sold in high-income countries, a process that gives cotton 
an enormous carbon footprint. Some countries produce 
their own clothing domestically, which cuts out this polluting stage, but generally, apparel production accounts
for 10% of global carbon emissions. And it's escalating. Cheaper garments and the public's
willingness to buy boosted global production 
from 1994 to 2014 by 400% to around 80 billion garments each year. Finally, in a consumer's home, the t-shirt goes through one of the most
resource-intensive phases of its lifetime. In America, for instance, the average household does nearly
400 loads of laundry per year each using about 40 gallons of water. Washing machines and dryers 
both use energy, with dryers requiring five to six times
more than washers. This dramatic shift in clothing 
consumption over the last 20 years, driven by large corporations
and the trend of fast fashion has cost the environment, the health of farmers, and driven questionable 
human labor practices. It's also turned fashion into the second
largest polluter in the world after oil. But there are things we can do. Consider shopping secondhand. Try to look for textiles made from
recycled or organic fabrics. Wash clothes less and line dry
to save resources. Instead of throwing them away
at the end of their life, donate, recycle, or reuse them
as cleaning rags. And, finally, you might ask yourself, how many t-shirts and articles of clothing
will you consume over your lifetime, and what will be their combined 
impact on the world?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Of the 22.7 million metric tons of cotton produced, ____ is grown organically.
Options: A. Less than 1%, B. Approximately 10%, C. None, D. All of it
Correct Option: A

Consider the classic white t-shirt. Annually, we sell and buy
two billion t-shirts globally, making it one of the most common

grown for the fluffy bolls they produce. Self-driving machines carefully harvest
these puffs, an industrial cotton gin mechanically
separates the fluffy bolls from the seeds, and the cotton lint is pressed 
into 225-kilogram bales. The cotton plants require a huge quantity
of water and pesticides. 2,700 liters of water are needed to produce
the average t-shirt, enough to fill more than 30 bathtubs. Meanwhile, cotton uses more insecticides
and pesticides than any other crop in the world. These pollutants can be carcinogenic, harm the health of field workers, and damage surrounding ecosystems. Some t-shirts are made of organic cotton
grown without pesticides and insecticides, but organic cotton makes up less than 1% of the 22.7 million metric tons 
of cotton produced worldwide. Once the cotton bales leave the farm, textile mills ship them
to a spinning facility, usually in China or India, where high-tech machines blend, card, comb, pull, stretch, and, finally, twist the cotton into
snowy ropes of yarn called slivers. Then, yarns are sent to the mill, where huge circular knitting machines weave them into sheets 
of rough grayish fabric treated with heat and chemicals
until they turn soft and white. Here, the fabric is dipped into
commercial bleaches and azo dyes, which make up the vivid coloring
in about 70% of textiles. Unfortunately, some of these contain
cancer-causing cadmium, lead, chromium, and mercury. Other harmful compounds and chemicals
can cause widespread contamination when released as toxic waste water
in rivers and oceans. Technologies are now so advanced
in some countries that the entire process of growing
and producing fabric barely touches a human hand. But only up until this point. After the finished cloth 
travels to factories, often in Bangladesh, China, India,
or Turkey, human labor is still required 
to stitch them up into t-shirts, intricate work that 
machines just can't do. This process has its own problems. Bangladesh, for example, which has surpassed China as the world's
biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts, employs 4.5 million people
in the t-shirt industry, but they typically face poor conditions
and low wages. After manufacture, all those t-shirts
travel by ship, train, and truck to be sold in high-income countries, a process that gives cotton 
an enormous carbon footprint. Some countries produce 
their own clothing domestically, which cuts out this polluting stage, but generally, apparel production accounts
for 10% of global carbon emissions. And it's escalating. Cheaper garments and the public's
willingness to buy boosted global production 
from 1994 to 2014 by 400% to around 80 billion garments each year. Finally, in a consumer's home, the t-shirt goes through one of the most
resource-intensive phases of its lifetime. In America, for instance, the average household does nearly
400 loads of laundry per year each using about 40 gallons of water. Washing machines and dryers

more than washers. This dramatic shift in clothing

recycled or organic fabrics. Wash clothes less and line dry
to save resources. Instead of throwing them away
at the end of their life, donate, recycle, or reuse them
as cleaning rags. And, finally, you might ask yourself, how many t-shirts and articles of clothing
will you consume over your lifetime, and what will be their combined 
impact on the world?

two billion t-shirts globally, making it one of the most common
garments in the world. But how and where is the average
t-shirt made, and what's its environmental impact? Clothing items can vary a lot, but a typical t-shirt begins its life
on a farm in America, China, or India where cotton seeds are sown, irrigated and
grown for the fluffy bolls they produce. Self-driving machines carefully harvest
these puffs, an industrial cotton gin mechanically
separates the fluffy bolls from the seeds, and the cotton lint is pressed 
into 225-kilogram bales. The cotton plants require a huge quantity
of water and pesticides. 2,700 liters of water are needed to produce
the average t-shirt, enough to fill more than 30 bathtubs. Meanwhile, cotton uses more insecticides
and pesticides than any other crop in the world. These pollutants can be carcinogenic, harm the health of field workers, and damage surrounding ecosystems. Some t-shirts are made of organic cotton
grown without pesticides and insecticides, but organic cotton makes up less than 1% of the 22.7 million metric tons 
of cotton produced worldwide. Once the cotton bales leave the farm, textile mills ship them
to a spinning facility, usually in China or India, where high-tech machines blend, card, comb, pull, stretch, and, finally, twist the cotton into
snowy ropes of yarn called slivers. Then, yarns are sent to the mill, where huge circular knitting machines weave them into sheets 
of rough grayish fabric treated with heat and chemicals
until they turn soft and white. Here, the fabric is dipped into
commercial bleaches and azo dyes, which make up the vivid coloring
in about 70% of textiles. Unfortunately, some of these contain
cancer-causing cadmium, lead, chromium, and mercury. Other harmful compounds and chemicals
can cause widespread contamination when released as toxic waste water
in rivers and oceans. Technologies are now so advanced
in some countries that the entire process of growing
and producing fabric barely touches a human hand. But only up until this point. After the finished cloth 
travels to factories, often in Bangladesh, China, India,
or Turkey, human labor is still required 
to stitch them up into t-shirts, intricate work that 
machines just can't do. This process has its own problems. Bangladesh, for example, which has surpassed China as the world's
biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts, employs 4.5 million people
in the t-shirt industry, but they typically face poor conditions
and low wages. After manufacture, all those t-shirts
travel by ship, train, and truck to be sold in high-income countries, a process that gives cotton 
an enormous carbon footprint. Some countries produce 
their own clothing domestically, which cuts out this polluting stage, but generally, apparel production accounts
for 10% of global carbon emissions. And it's escalating. Cheaper garments and the public's
willingness to buy boosted global production 
from 1994 to 2014 by 400% to around 80 billion garments each year. Finally, in a consumer's home, the t-shirt goes through one of the most
resource-intensive phases of its lifetime. In America, for instance, the average household does nearly
400 loads of laundry per year each using about 40 gallons of water. Washing machines and dryers 
both use energy, with dryers requiring five to six times
more than washers. This dramatic shift in clothing 
consumption over the last 20 years, driven by large corporations
and the trend of fast fashion has cost the environment, the health of farmers, and driven questionable 
human labor practices. It's also turned fashion into the second
largest polluter in the world after oil. But there are things we can do. Consider shopping secondhand. Try to look for textiles made from
recycled or organic fabrics. Wash clothes less and line dry
to save resources. Instead of throwing them away
at the end of their life, donate, recycle, or reuse them
as cleaning rags. And, finally, you might ask yourself, how many t-shirts and articles of clothing
will you consume over your lifetime, and what will be their combined 
impact on the world?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If you decreased the amount of laundry loads in your household to 100 less than the average, how much water would you save per year?
Options: A. 200 gallons, B. 400 gallons, C. 600 gallons, D. 800 gallons
Correct Option: B

Question 1: What is the common myth about the brain's left and right sides that is unsupported by scientific evidence? Options: A. The left side controls language and the right side controls creativity., D. The left side controls logic and the right side controls creativity. Correct Option: D
Question 2: What theory suggests that the crossing over of visual fields in the brain gave animals a survival advantage? Options: A. The Broca-Wernicke theory, B. The theory of quick reflexes, C. The theory of complex nervous systems, D. The theory of predator avoidance Correct Option: C
Question 3: What happens when an animal sees a predator coming from its left side? Options: A. It turns left to escape., B. It turns right to escape., C. It stays still., D. It attacks the predator. Correct Option: B

The authors of the transcript, D. The researchers who studied the brain's left and right sides Correct Option: A

They show only logical behaviors., C. They show only creative behaviors., D. They show no behaviors at all. Correct Option: A

The brain's left and right sides are separate and distinct., C. The brain's left and right sides work together to control various functions, and there is no evidence to support the idea of a left-right split between logic and creativity., D. The brain's left and right sides are not important for controlling functions. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between logic and creativity? Options: A. They are at odds with each other., B. They are separate and distinct., C. They are interconnected and interdependent., D. They are not related. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the significance of the crossing over of visual fields in the brain? Options: A. It allows animals to see the world in a more complex way., B. It allows animals to move their eyes independently., C. It gives animals a survival advantage by allowing them to react quickly to predators., D. It has no significance for animal behavior. Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
"Beauty is a curse," Psyche thought as she looked over the cliff's edge
where she'd been abandoned by her father. She'd been born with the physical
perfection so complete that she was worshipped as a new
incarnation of Venus, the goddess of love. But real-life human lovers were
too intimidated even to approach her. When her father asked for guidance
from the Oracle of Apollo, the god of light, reason, and prophecy. He was told to abandon his daughter
on a rocky crag where she would marry a cruel
and savage serpent-like winged evil. Alone on the crag, Psyche felt
Zephyr the West Wind gently lifting her into the air. It set her down before a palace. "You are home," she heard 
an unseen voice say. "Your husband awaits you
in the bedroom, if you dare to meet him." She was brave enough, Psyche told herself. The bedroom was so dark that she
couldn't see her husband. But he didn't feel serpent-like at all. His skin was soft,
and his voice and manner were gentle. She asked him who he was, but he told her this was the one question
he could never answer. If she loved him, 
she would not need to know. His visits continued night after night. Before long, Psyche was pregnant. She rejoiced, but was also conflicted. How could she raise her baby
with a man she'd never seen? That night, Psyche approached
her sleeping husband holding an oil lamp. What she found was the god Cupid who sent gods and humans 
lusting after each other with the pinpricks of his arrows. Psyche dropped her lamp,
burning Cupid with hot oil. He said he'd been in love with Psyche
ever since his jealous mother, Venus, asked him to embarrass the young woman
by pricking her with an arrow. But taken with Psyche's beauty, Cupid
used the arrow on himself. He didn't believe, however, that gods
and humans could love as equals. Now that she knew his true form,
their hopes for happiness were dashed, so he flew away. Psyche was left in despair until
the unseen voice returned and told her that it was indeed possible for her and Cupid 
to love each other as equals. Encouraged, she set out to find him. But Venus intercepted Psyche and said
she and Cupid could only wed if she completed a series 
of impossible tasks. First, Psyche was told to sort a huge,
messy pile of seeds in a single night. Just as she was abandoning hope, an ant colony took pity on her
and helped with the work. Successfully passing the first trial, Psyche next had to bring Venus
the fleece of the golden sheep, who had a reputation for 
disemboweling stray adventurers, but a river god showed her how to collect the fleece the sheep 
had snagged on briars, and she succeeded. Finally, Psyche had to travel
to the Underworld and convince Proserpina, 
queen of the dead, to put a drop of her beauty in a box
for Venus. Once again, the unseen voice came
to Psyche's aide. It told her to bring barley cakes for
Cerberus, the guard dog to the Underworld and coins to pay the boatman, Charon
to ferry her across the river Styx. With her third and final task complete, Psyche returned to the land of the living. Just outside Venus's palace, she opened
the box of Proserpina's beauty, hoping to keep some for herself. But the box was filled with sleep,
not beauty, and Psyche collapsed in the road. Cupid, now recovered from his wounds,
flew to his sleeping bride. He told her he'd been wrong and foolish. Her fearlessness in the face
of the unknown proved that she was more than his equal. Cupid gave Psyche amborsia, the nectar
of the gods, making her immortal. Shortly after, Psyche bore their daughter. They named her Pleasure, and she, Cupid, and Psyche, 
whose name means soul, have been complicating people's
love lives ever since.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Cupid makes people fall in love with each other:
Options: A. By pricking them with an arrow, B. By setting them up on blind dates, C. By casting a spell, D. Though his mother Venus, goddess of love
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Approximately how many metric tons of caffeine are consumed around the world every year? Options: A. 10,000, B. 50,000, C. 100,000, D. 500,000 Correct Option: C
Question 2: What are some common sources of caffeine, apart from coffee and tea? Options: A. Chocolate and caffeine pills, B. Soda and decaf beverages, C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the primary function of caffeine in plants? Options: A. To attract insects, B. To repel insects, C. To help insects remember and revisit flowers, D. To make plants more toxic Correct Option: C
Question 4: How does caffeine keep us awake? Options: A. By blocking the release of dopamine, B. By blocking the production of ATP, C. By blocking one of the body's key sleep-inducing molecules, adenosine, D. By increasing the production of adenosine Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the role of adenosine in the brain? Options: A. To promote feelings of pleasure, B. To slow down the release of brain-signaling molecules, C. To increase the production of dopamine, D. To decrease the production of caffeine Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the effect of caffeine on the adenosine receptors in the brain? Options: A. It activates them, B. It blocks them, C. It has no effect on them, D. It increases their production Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the potential long-term benefit of caffeine consumption? Options: A. Reducing the risk of diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, B. Increasing the risk of diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, C. Having no effect on the risk of diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, D. Both A and B Correct Option: A
Question 8: Why do some sports organizations place limits on caffeine consumption? Options: A. Because it can increase the risk of diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, B. Because it can give athletes an unfair advantage, C. Because it can decrease the risk of diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, D. Because it has no effect on athletic performance Correct Option: B
Question 9: What happens to the body when it adapts to regular caffeine consumption? Options: A. It manufactures fewer adenosine receptors, B. It manufactures more adenosine receptors, C. It has no effect on adenosine receptors, D. It decreases the production of adenosine Correct Option: B
Question 10: What happens to the body when it suddenly quits caffeine consumption? Options: A. It experiences no withdrawal symptoms, B. It experiences headaches, tiredness, and depressed moods, C. It experiences an increase in energy levels, D. It experiences a decrease in energy levels Correct Option: B
Question 11: What is the molecular structure of caffeine similar to? Options: A. Adenosine, B. Dopamine, C. ATP, D. Glucose Correct Option: A
Question 12: What is the role of dopamine in the brain? Options: A. To slow down the release of brain-signaling molecules, B. To promote feelings of pleasure, C. To increase the production of adenosine, D. To decrease the production of caffeine Correct Option: B
Question 13: How does caffeine affect the body's ability to burn fat? Options: A. It decreases the body's ability to burn fat, B. It increases the body's ability to burn fat, C. It has no effect on the body's ability to burn fat, D. It decreases the body's energy levels Correct Option: None
Question 14: What is the consequence of consuming more and more caffeine to feel alert? Options: A. The body adapts and manufactures fewer adenosine receptors, B. The body adapts and manufactures more adenosine receptors, C. The body has no effect on adenosine receptors, D. The body decreases the production of adenosine Correct Option: B
Question 15: What is the consequence of suddenly quitting caffeine consumption after regular use? Options: A. The body experiences no withdrawal symptoms, B. The body experiences headaches, tiredness, and depressed moods, C. The body experiences an increase in energy levels, D. The body experiences a decrease in energy levels Correct Option: B
Question 16: What is the effect of caffeine on dopamine receptors in the brain? Options: A. It decreases the production of dopamine, B. It increases the production of dopamine, C. It blocks the receptors for dopamine, D. It has no effect on dopamine receptors Correct Option: C
Question 17: What is the relationship between caffeine and the body's ability to burn fat? Options: A. Caffeine decreases the body's ability to burn fat, B. Caffeine increases the body's ability to burn fat, C. Caffeine has no effect on the body's ability to burn fat, D. The relationship is not supported by the transcript Correct Option: B

where she'd been abandoned by her father. She'd been born with the physical
perfection so complete that she was worshipped as a new
incarnation of Venus, the goddess of love. But real-life human lovers were
too intimidated even to approach her. When her father asked for guidance
from the Oracle of Apollo, the god of light, reason, and prophecy. He was told to abandon his daughter
on a rocky crag where she would marry a cruel
and savage serpent-like winged evil. Alone on the crag, Psyche felt
Zephyr the West Wind gently lifting her into the air. It set her down before a palace. "You are home," she heard 
an unseen voice say. "Your husband awaits you
in the bedroom, if you dare to meet him." She was brave enough, Psyche told herself. The bedroom was so dark that she
couldn't see her husband. But he didn't feel serpent-like at all. His skin was soft,
and his voice and manner were gentle. She asked him who he was, but he told her this was the one question
he could never answer. If she loved him, 
she would not need to know. His visits continued night after night. Before long, Psyche was pregnant. She rejoiced, but was also conflicted. How could she raise her baby
with a man she'd never seen? That night, Psyche approached
her sleeping husband holding an oil lamp. What she found was the god Cupid who sent gods and humans 
lusting after each other with the pinpricks of his arrows. Psyche dropped her lamp,
burning Cupid with hot oil. He said he'd been in love with Psyche
ever since his jealous mother, Venus, asked him to embarrass the young woman
by pricking her with an arrow. But taken with Psyche's beauty, Cupid
used the arrow on himself. He didn't believe, however, that gods
and humans could love as equals. Now that she knew his true form,
their hopes for happiness were dashed, so he flew away. Psyche was left in despair until

to love each other as equals. Encouraged, she set out to find him. But Venus intercepted Psyche and said
she and Cupid could only wed if she completed a series 
of impossible tasks. First, Psyche was told to sort a huge,

of the unknown proved that she was more than his equal. Cupid gave Psyche amborsia, the nectar
of the gods, making her immortal. Shortly after, Psyche bore their daughter. They named her Pleasure, and she, Cupid, and Psyche, 
whose name means soul, have been complicating people's
love lives ever since.

"Beauty is a curse," Psyche thought as she looked over the cliff's edge
where she'd been abandoned by her father. She'd been born with the physical
perfection so complete that she was worshipped as a new
incarnation of Venus, the goddess of love. But real-life human lovers were
too intimidated even to approach her. When her father asked for guidance
from the Oracle of Apollo, the god of light, reason, and prophecy. He was told to abandon his daughter
on a rocky crag where she would marry a cruel
and savage serpent-like winged evil. Alone on the crag, Psyche felt
Zephyr the West Wind gently lifting her into the air. It set her down before a palace. "You are home," she heard 
an unseen voice say. "Your husband awaits you
in the bedroom, if you dare to meet him." She was brave enough, Psyche told herself. The bedroom was so dark that she
couldn't see her husband. But he didn't feel serpent-like at all. His skin was soft,
and his voice and manner were gentle. She asked him who he was, but he told her this was the one question
he could never answer. If she loved him, 
she would not need to know. His visits continued night after night. Before long, Psyche was pregnant. She rejoiced, but was also conflicted. How could she raise her baby
with a man she'd never seen? That night, Psyche approached
her sleeping husband holding an oil lamp. What she found was the god Cupid who sent gods and humans 
lusting after each other with the pinpricks of his arrows. Psyche dropped her lamp,
burning Cupid with hot oil. He said he'd been in love with Psyche
ever since his jealous mother, Venus, asked him to embarrass the young woman
by pricking her with an arrow. But taken with Psyche's beauty, Cupid
used the arrow on himself. He didn't believe, however, that gods
and humans could love as equals. Now that she knew his true form,
their hopes for happiness were dashed, so he flew away. Psyche was left in despair until
the unseen voice returned and told her that it was indeed possible for her and Cupid 
to love each other as equals. Encouraged, she set out to find him. But Venus intercepted Psyche and said
she and Cupid could only wed if she completed a series 
of impossible tasks. First, Psyche was told to sort a huge,
messy pile of seeds in a single night. Just as she was abandoning hope, an ant colony took pity on her
and helped with the work. Successfully passing the first trial, Psyche next had to bring Venus
the fleece of the golden sheep, who had a reputation for

had snagged on briars, and she succeeded. Finally, Psyche had to travel

queen of the dead, to put a drop of her beauty in a box
for Venus. Once again, the unseen voice came

of the gods, making her immortal. Shortly after, Psyche bore their daughter. They named her Pleasure, and she, Cupid, and Psyche, 
whose name means soul, have been complicating people's
love lives ever since.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Venus is jealous of Psyche because:
Options: A. Cupid falls in love with Psyche, B. Psyche is brave, C. Psyche drinks ambrosia, becoming immortal like a god, D. Psyche steals beauty from the underworld, E. Psyche is so beautiful she attracts her own worshippers, like a god
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Approximately how many metric tons of caffeine are consumed around the world every year? Options: A. 10,000, B. 50,000, C. 100,000, D. 500,000 Correct Option: C
Question 2: What are some common sources of caffeine, apart from coffee and tea? Options: A. Chocolate and caffeine pills, B. Soda and decaf beverages, C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the primary function of caffeine in plants? Options: A. To attract insects, B. To repel insects, C. To help insects remember and revisit flowers, D. To make plants more toxic Correct Option: C
Question 4: How does caffeine keep us awake? Options: A. By blocking the release of dopamine, B. By blocking the production of ATP, C. By blocking one of the body's key sleep-inducing molecules, adenosine, D. By increasing the production of adenosine Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the role of adenosine in the brain? Options: A. To promote feelings of pleasure, B. To slow down the release of brain-signaling molecules, C. To increase the production of dopamine, D. To decrease the production of caffeine Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the effect of caffeine on the adenosine receptors in the brain? Options: A. It activates them, B. It blocks them, C. It has no effect on them, D. It increases their production Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the potential long-term benefit of caffeine consumption? Options: A. Reducing the risk of diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, B. Increasing the risk of diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, C. Having no effect on the risk of diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, D. Both A and B Correct Option: A
Question 8: Why do some sports organizations place limits on caffeine consumption? Options: A. Because it can increase the risk of diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, B. Because it can give athletes an unfair advantage, C. Because it can decrease the risk of diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, D. Because it has no effect on athletic performance Correct Option: B

It experiences an increase in energy levels, D. It experiences a decrease in energy levels Correct Option: B

Question 12: What is the role of dopamine in the brain? Options: A. To slow down the release of brain-signaling molecules, B. To promote feelings of pleasure, C. To increase the production of adenosine, D. To decrease the production of caffeine Correct Option: B

Question 14: What is the consequence of consuming more and more caffeine to feel alert? Options: A. The body adapts and manufactures fewer adenosine receptors, B. The body adapts and manufactures more adenosine receptors, C. The body has no effect on adenosine receptors, D. The body decreases the production of adenosine Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
"Beauty is a curse," Psyche thought as she looked over the cliff's edge
where she'd been abandoned by her father. She'd been born with the physical
perfection so complete that she was worshipped as a new
incarnation of Venus, the goddess of love. But real-life human lovers were
too intimidated even to approach her. When her father asked for guidance
from the Oracle of Apollo, the god of light, reason, and prophecy. He was told to abandon his daughter
on a rocky crag where she would marry a cruel
and savage serpent-like winged evil. Alone on the crag, Psyche felt
Zephyr the West Wind gently lifting her into the air. It set her down before a palace. "You are home," she heard 
an unseen voice say. "Your husband awaits you
in the bedroom, if you dare to meet him." She was brave enough, Psyche told herself. The bedroom was so dark that she
couldn't see her husband. But he didn't feel serpent-like at all. His skin was soft,
and his voice and manner were gentle. She asked him who he was, but he told her this was the one question
he could never answer. If she loved him, 
she would not need to know. His visits continued night after night. Before long, Psyche was pregnant. She rejoiced, but was also conflicted. How could she raise her baby
with a man she'd never seen? That night, Psyche approached
her sleeping husband holding an oil lamp. What she found was the god Cupid who sent gods and humans 
lusting after each other with the pinpricks of his arrows. Psyche dropped her lamp,
burning Cupid with hot oil. He said he'd been in love with Psyche
ever since his jealous mother, Venus, asked him to embarrass the young woman
by pricking her with an arrow. But taken with Psyche's beauty, Cupid
used the arrow on himself. He didn't believe, however, that gods
and humans could love as equals. Now that she knew his true form,
their hopes for happiness were dashed, so he flew away. Psyche was left in despair until
the unseen voice returned and told her that it was indeed possible for her and Cupid 
to love each other as equals. Encouraged, she set out to find him. But Venus intercepted Psyche and said
she and Cupid could only wed if she completed a series 
of impossible tasks. First, Psyche was told to sort a huge,
messy pile of seeds in a single night. Just as she was abandoning hope, an ant colony took pity on her
and helped with the work. Successfully passing the first trial, Psyche next had to bring Venus
the fleece of the golden sheep, who had a reputation for 
disemboweling stray adventurers, but a river god showed her how to collect the fleece the sheep 
had snagged on briars, and she succeeded. Finally, Psyche had to travel
to the Underworld and convince Proserpina, 
queen of the dead, to put a drop of her beauty in a box
for Venus. Once again, the unseen voice came
to Psyche's aide. It told her to bring barley cakes for
Cerberus, the guard dog to the Underworld and coins to pay the boatman, Charon
to ferry her across the river Styx. With her third and final task complete, Psyche returned to the land of the living. Just outside Venus's palace, she opened
the box of Proserpina's beauty, hoping to keep some for herself. But the box was filled with sleep,
not beauty, and Psyche collapsed in the road. Cupid, now recovered from his wounds,
flew to his sleeping bride. He told her he'd been wrong and foolish. Her fearlessness in the face
of the unknown proved that she was more than his equal. Cupid gave Psyche amborsia, the nectar
of the gods, making her immortal. Shortly after, Psyche bore their daughter. They named her Pleasure, and she, Cupid, and Psyche, 
whose name means soul, have been complicating people's
love lives ever since.

Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Behold the human brain, it's lumpy landscape visibly split into
a left and right side. This structure has inspired one of 
the most pervasive ideas about the brain, that the left side controls logic and the right, creativity. And yet, this is a myth unsupported
by scientific evidence. So how did this misleading idea
come about, and what does it get wrong? It's true that the brain has a right
and a left side. This is most apparent 
with the outer layer, or the cortex. Internal regions, like the striatum, hypothalamus, thalamus, and brain stem appear to be made from continuous tissue, but in fact, they're also organized
with left and right sides. The left and the right sides of the brain
do control different body functions, such as movement and sight. The brain's right side controls the motion
of the left arm and leg and vice versa. The visual system is even more complex. Each eye has a left 
and right visual field. Both left visual fields are sent
to the right side of the brain, and both right fields 
are sent to the left side. So the brain uses both sides to make
a complete image of the world. Scientists don't know for sure
why we have that crossing over. One theory is it began soon after animals
developed more complex nervous systems because it gave the survival advantage
of quicker reflexes. If an animal sees a predator coming
from its left side, it's best off escaping to the right. So we can say that vision 
and movement control are two systems that rely on this left-right structure, but problems arise when we over-extend
that idea to logic and creativity. This misconception began in 
the mid-1800s when two neurologists, Broca and Wernicke, examined patients who had problems
communicating due to injuries. The researchers found damage to
the patients' left temporal lobes, so they suggested that language is
controlled by the left side of the brain. That captured the popular imagination. Author Robert Louis Stevenson then introduced the idea 
of a logical left hemisphere competing with an emotional 
right hemisphere represented by his characters
Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. But this idea didn't hold up when doctors
and scientists examined patients who were missing
a hemisphere or had their two hemispheres separated. These patients showed a complete
range of behaviors, both logical and creative. Later research showed that one side
of the brain is more active than the other for some functions. Language is more localized to the left and attention to the right. So one side of the brain may do more work, but this varies by system
rather than by person. There isn't any evidence to suggest that individuals have dominant 
sides of the brain, or to support the idea 
of a left-right split between logic and creativity. Some people may be particularly logical
or creative, but that has nothing to do with the sides
of their brains. And even the idea of logic and creativity
being at odds with each other doesn't hold up well. Solving complex math problems requires
inspired creativity and many vibrant works of art
have intricate logical frameworks. Almost every feat of creativity and logic carries the mark of the whole brain
functioning as one.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which statement below is a myth?
Options: A. The human brain is clearly divided into two parts, B. The left side of the brain controls logic, and the right controls creativity, C. The outer layer of the brain is called the cortex, D. Both a and b are myths
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:

You should never question the accuracy of a graph., D. You should only consider the context of the graph. Correct Option: A

Cherry picking is a technique used to manipulate the y-axis of a graph., C. The transcript does not mention any techniques used to manipulate graphs., D. The transcript does not discuss cherry picking. Correct Option: A

The transcript only talks about the use of graphs in advertising., C. The transcript does not mention any techniques used to manipulate graphs., D. The transcript does not discuss the importance of understanding the significance of data in a graph. Correct Option: A

Cherry picking is a technique used to manipulate the x-axis of a graph by carefully choosing a time range and data points to exclude the impact of a major event., B. Graphs can only be used to show trends over time., C. You should never question the accuracy of a graph., D. The transcript does not mention cherry picking. Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Behold the human brain, it's lumpy landscape visibly split into
a left and right side. This structure has inspired one of 
the most pervasive ideas about the brain, that the left side controls logic and the right, creativity. And yet, this is a myth unsupported
by scientific evidence. So how did this misleading idea
come about, and what does it get wrong? It's true that the brain has a right
and a left side. This is most apparent 
with the outer layer, or the cortex. Internal regions, like the striatum, hypothalamus, thalamus, and brain stem appear to be made from continuous tissue, but in fact, they're also organized
with left and right sides. The left and the right sides of the brain
do control different body functions, such as movement and sight. The brain's right side controls the motion
of the left arm and leg and vice versa. The visual system is even more complex. Each eye has a left 
and right visual field. Both left visual fields are sent
to the right side of the brain, and both right fields 
are sent to the left side. So the brain uses both sides to make
a complete image of the world. Scientists don't know for sure
why we have that crossing over. One theory is it began soon after animals
developed more complex nervous systems because it gave the survival advantage
of quicker reflexes. If an animal sees a predator coming
from its left side, it's best off escaping to the right. So we can say that vision 
and movement control are two systems that rely on this left-right structure, but problems arise when we over-extend
that idea to logic and creativity. This misconception began in 
the mid-1800s when two neurologists, Broca and Wernicke, examined patients who had problems
communicating due to injuries. The researchers found damage to
the patients' left temporal lobes, so they suggested that language is
controlled by the left side of the brain. That captured the popular imagination. Author Robert Louis Stevenson then introduced the idea 
of a logical left hemisphere competing with an emotional 
right hemisphere represented by his characters
Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. But this idea didn't hold up when doctors
and scientists examined patients who were missing
a hemisphere or had their two hemispheres separated. These patients showed a complete
range of behaviors, both logical and creative. Later research showed that one side
of the brain is more active than the other for some functions. Language is more localized to the left and attention to the right. So one side of the brain may do more work, but this varies by system
rather than by person. There isn't any evidence to suggest that individuals have dominant 
sides of the brain, or to support the idea 
of a left-right split between logic and creativity. Some people may be particularly logical
or creative, but that has nothing to do with the sides
of their brains. And even the idea of logic and creativity
being at odds with each other doesn't hold up well. Solving complex math problems requires
inspired creativity and many vibrant works of art
have intricate logical frameworks. Almost every feat of creativity and logic carries the mark of the whole brain
functioning as one.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The right side of the brain controls the movement of the:
Options: A. Right side arm and leg, B. Left side arm and leg, C. Both arms and legs, D. The eyes
Correct Option: B

Question 7: **Knowledge** Options: A. Cherry picking is a technique used to manipulate the x-axis of a graph by carefully choosing a time range and data points to exclude the impact of a major event., B. Cherry picking is a technique used to manipulate the y-axis of a graph., C. A graph can only be used to show data from one point in time., D. The transcript does not mention cherry picking. Correct Option: A
Question 8: **Comprehension** Options: A. The transcript explains how graphs can be used to mislead and manipulate data, and the importance of understanding the significance of data in a graph., B. The transcript only talks about the use of graphs in advertising., C. The transcript does not mention any techniques used to manipulate graphs., D. The transcript does not discuss the importance of understanding the significance of data in a graph. Correct Option: A
Question 9: **Application** Options: A. When analyzing a graph, consider the numbers, labels, context, and significance of the data., B. When analyzing a graph, consider the context and significance of the data., C. Graphs can only be used to show trends over time. Correct Option: A
Question 10: **Evaluation** Options: A. Cherry picking is a technique used to manipulate the x-axis of a graph by carefully choosing a time range and data points to exclude the impact of a major event., B. Graphs can only be used to show trends over time., C. You should never question the accuracy of a graph., D. The transcript does not mention cherry picking. Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Over 100,000 metric tons
of caffeine are consumed around the world every year. That's equivalent to the weight
of 14 Eiffel Towers. Most of this caffeine is consumed
in coffee and tea, but it's also ingested in some sodas, chocolate, caffeine pills, and even beverages labeled decaf. Caffeine helps us feel alert,
focused, happy, and energetic, even if we haven't had enough sleep. But it can also raise our blood pressure,
and make us feel anxious. It's the world most widely used drug. So how does it keep us awake? Caffeine evolved in plants where
it serves a few purposes. In high doses, as it's found in the leaves
and seeds of certain species, it's toxic to insects. But when they consume it in lower doses,
as it's found in nectar, it can actually help them remember
and revisit flowers. In the human body, caffeine acts as a
stimulant for the central nervous system. It keeps us awake by blocking one of
the body's key sleep-inducing molecules, a substance called adenosine. Your body needs a constant supply
of energy, which it gets by breaking down
a high-energy molecule called ATP. In the process, it liberates adenosine,
ATP's chemical backbone. Neurons in your brain have receptors
perfectly tailored to this molecule. When adenosine docks to these receptors, it activates a cascade 
of biochemical reactions that cause neurons to fire more sluggishly and slow the release of important
brain-signaling molecules. In other words, you get sleepy. Caffeine is what's called an adenosine
receptor antagonist. That means it derails this process
of slowing your neurons down by blocking adenosine receptors. Caffeine and adenosine have a similar
molecular structure, close enough that caffeine can wedge into
the adenosine receptors, but not close enough to activate them. To summarize, 
adenosine inhibits your neurons. Caffeine inhibits the inhibitor,
so it stimulates you. Caffeine can also boost positive feelings. In some neurons, the adenosine receptors are linked to receptors 
for another molecule called dopamine. One of dopamine's roles in the brain
is to promote feelings of pleasure. When adenosine docks in one of these
paired receptors, that can make it harder for dopamine
to fit in its own spot, interrupting its mood-lifting work. But when caffeine takes adenosine's place,
it doesn't have the same effect, and dopamine can slide in. There's evidence that caffeine's effects
on adenosine and dopamine receptors can have long-term benefits, too,
reducing the risk of diseases like Parkinson's, Alzheimer's,
and some types of cancer. Caffeine can also ramp up the body's
ability to burn fat. In fact, some sports organizations think that caffeine gives athletes 
an unfair advantage and have placed limits on its consumption. From 1972 until 2004, Olympic athletes had to stay below
a certain blood-caffeine concentration to compete. Of course, not all of caffeine's effects
are so helpful. It might make you feel better
and more alert, but it can also raise your heart rate
and blood pressure, cause increased urination or diarrhea, and contribute to insomnia and anxiety. Plus, the foods and beverages
caffeine is found in have their own impacts on your body
that have to be taken into account. Your brain can adapt to regular
consumption of caffeine. If your adenosine receptors 
are perpetually clogged, your body will manufacture extra ones. That way, even with caffeine around, adenosine can still do its job
of signaling the brain to power down. That's why you may find you need
to consume more and more caffeine to feel as alert. There are more and more adenosine
receptors to block. It's also why if you suddenly 
quit caffeine, you may experience 
an unpleasant withdrawal. With plenty of receptors 
and no competition, adenosine can work overtime, causing symptoms like headaches, tiredness, and depressed moods. But in a few days, the extra adenosine
receptors will disappear, your body will readjust, and you'll feel just as alert as ever, even without an infusion of the world's
most popular stimulant.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following isn’t a caffeine source?
Options: A. Some sodas, B. Chocolate, C. Energy drinks, D. Decaf coffee, E. None of the above
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the largest kidney stone on record known to have formed? Options: A. 1 kilogram in weight, B. 17 centimeters in diameter, C. 10 centimeters in diameter, D. 5 millimeters in diameter Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the most common type of crystal to form a kidney stone? Options: A. Calcium phosphate, B. Uric acid, C. Calcium oxalate, D. Magnesium ammonium phosphate Correct Option: C
Question 3: What can happen if a kidney stone blocks the flow of urine? Options: A. Infection and damage to the kidneys, B. Nausea and vomiting, C. A burning sensation while urinating, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 4: A doctor may recommend drinking large amounts of water to help pass a kidney stone. What is the purpose of this recommendation? Options: A. To dissolve the stone, B. To make the stone larger, C. To help the stone pass more easily, D. To make the stone more painful Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the purpose of using extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy to treat a kidney stone? Options: A. To crush the stone into smaller pieces, B. To dissolve the stone, C. To make the stone larger, D. To make the stone more painful Correct Option: A
Question 6: What can happen if a kidney stone is not treated? Options: A. It will pass out of the body on its own, B. It will become smaller, C. It can cause pain and potentially damage the kidneys, D. It will dissolve in the urine Correct Option: C
Question 7: What are some foods that a doctor may advise limiting to prevent kidney stones? Options: A. Foods high in calcium, B. Foods high in oxalate, C. Foods high in sodium, D. All of the above Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the role of calcium in preventing kidney stones? Options: A. Calcium can contribute to the formation of kidney stones, B. Calcium can help bind to oxalate in the digestive tract, C. Calcium has no effect on kidney stone formation, D. Calcium can dissolve kidney stones Correct Option: B
Question 9: What are some potential complications of kidney stones? Options: A. Infection and damage to the kidneys, B. Nausea and vomiting, C. A burning sensation while urinating, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is a key factor in preventing kidney stones? Options: A. Eating foods high in oxalate, B. Drinking plenty of water, C. Taking medications to dissolve the stone, D. Avoiding all foods high in oxalate Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The generated MCQs appear to be related to kidney stones, whereas the ground truth MCQ is about caffeine sources.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the multiple-choice format and the presence of options, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are similar to the ground truth MCQ.

But if you insist on an index, I would say -1 or "None" to indicate that there is no matching generated MCQ.

If you want, I can try to generate a new MCQ that matches the ground truth MCQ.
